Oh man. Brawlhalla. I really thought this game had the potential to be a really fun game back in 2018. I spend at least 200 hours on PC alone with the majority of my almost 1,000 hours going to Playstation, cross play comes along and suddenly, it feels like every attack from every legend in this game do pretty much the same things but in a different a flashy way. 

The mobility options in this game makes it feel like I'm playing cat and mouse simulator because the most optimal way to play this game is to wait for your opponent to make make a mistake and then bash them in the face with your weapon's highest damage combo while their dodge is on cooldown. this is the most tilt inducing game I've ever played in my life and if you have never played a fighting game before, this is not the fighting game for you if you want to get invested into a fighting game. if you have played a fighting game before, the initial skill curve is pretty low, and there are many ways to make the game as unenjoyable as possible to play for your opponent at all levels of play because you can easily create situations for your opponent to be put in a terrible position and waste all of their defensive options, even without knowing any game sense. 

Speaking of defensive options, they are god awful. being able to use attacks mid string after being punished for a bad dodge to deny your opponent of their well deserved string is absolutely absurd and requires no foresight to utilize. there should have been at least 1 other defensive option to create an opportunity to counter attack through deep understanding of defensive mechanics in any fighting but they are not complicated at all. The only defensive options in this game are to use your dodge, perform a wake up attack that has higher priority and lower start up frames than your opponent's attack which is likely to happen with many weapons have a low start up frames, or to avoid your opponent all together which, quiet frankly, is the very reason I am making this review. 

This is by far the worst fighting game I have ever played and is the last thing I ever want to see on my profile, and in my invite inbox. I genuinely regret thinking this game takes brain cells when really you don't need to think too hard to pull of easy strats, especially when they are the most optimal strats in the game. And if you manage to consistently play the easiest way possible in high plat and above and get rewarded for it, there is clearly a problem with the game fundamentally.

This game is pretty good, but not quite as good as Cinnamon Pull Apart Bread!

What you'll need:

- A 9x13 Pan (preferably glass)
- Non Stick Spray
- 2 Tubes of Biscuits (Pillsbury or Otherwise)
- 1 and 1/2 sticks of Salted Butter (Unsalted also works, just be sure to add a 1/2 teaspoon of salt in step 3)
- 4 Teaspoons of Brown Sugar
- 1 Teaspoon of Cinnamon
- 1 Tablespoon of Honey
- 2 Tablespoons of Milk, Heavy Cream, or Buttermilk (Non-Dairy Milks work as well. See Step for more info) (More as Needed)
- 2 Cups of Powdered Sugar (more as needed)

Step 1. Preheat your oven to 350 and give your pan a light coat of non-stick spray

Step 2. POP THEM BISCUITS OPEN BABY!!

Once you get the biscuits out, grab a butterknife (or use your hands you filthy animal) and quarter them. Start laying em out in the pan. Spaces in-between the biscuits is A-okay cause we want that buttersugar to get down in there once we start pouring. Likely, you'll run into the issue of "too many biscuit pieces, not enough space" so just kinda squish em down and try to fill in the edges and corners with an extra biscuit piece. Once you've got all the biscuits packed in there, we're on to step 3!

Step 3. BUTTERSUGAR TIME

Grab your 1 and 1/2 Sticks of butter and we're gon' melt that son of a gun. Personally, I like to melt butter in the microwave, but if you wanna get all fancy and pull out the saucepan then go for it. Ain't nobody stopping you.

So for the rest of us common folk, put your butter in a microwave safe bowl or Pyrex measuring cup. I throw it in there for like 1min and just check on it closer to the minute mark, but we all got different microwaves. Basically, you just want the butter to be melted with no chunks left in it. So however long it takes to do that. DON'T leave it in too long or it'll burn and then you gotta go get more butter.

NOW. You've got your melted butter. Add the Cinnamon and the brown sugar to it and stir the everliving life outta that thing til' it's all nice and pretty. Once you've successfully crafted the buttersugar, pour it over the biscuits in the pan. My two main goals here are "1. Make sure every biscuit gets some love" and "2. Fill in all the cracks" So pour slow and steady.

Step 4. MAKE IT HOT

Okay. Let me level with you here. I am not a classically trained baking professional. I'm just a regular schmegular person who likes the sweety sweets. I have ♥♥♥♥♥♥ these up before and this is the step that made my spouse leave.

Double check the oven is on 350. Put the little biscuits in the oven so that they can grow up to be big and strong. Leave them in there for about 10-13min. Be sure to check on your biscuits throughout the process. What you're looking for is the tops to be golden brown. Like that real fresh baked brown, that you see in the movies and tv and recipe sites. Once you see golden brown, open the oven and don't be afraid to get a little greedy. Grab a biscuit off the top so you can see how the middle section and bottom of the pan look.

If it looks doughy Turn the oven off and let the biscuits sit inside for maybe 5 minutes. Again, note the color of the tops and go back to your reference piece that you took out. You want them to look like done biscuits. I can't put pictures but I'll make a guide if people are interested and go back through all the steps with pictures.

If it doesn't look doughy Well then what the ♥♥♥♥ are you doing? Move on to the next step champ! We got biscuits to eat!

Step 5. Make the Glaze

In a good sized bowl, whisk together your Powdered sugar, honey, and milk. If you don't have a whisk, that's fine. Just go grab a utensil or something. Personal preference: Fork. They look meaner than the other utensils.

NON-DAIRY MILK USERS UNITE!
I really like an almond milk substitute here, but whatever works, works. Just know, with the amount of ingredients we're using here, your glaze may come out thin and runny. If it does, don't panic and cry. Just add a little more powdered sugar in tablespoon increments. Add, whisk and repeat if it still comes out runny. Once it's thick enough, go ahead on.

Take your whisked mixture and and drizzle it over the finished biscuits. And boom done. You just baked something delicious.

If you read this far, thank you. If you liked the recipe, thank you. I'll try to make a guide and go back through with pictures and gifs to make this a lot easier to follow if enough people want that.

Call the ones you love, tell em you love them.

Let me know what recipe you want me to do next.

As fun characters as this game has, I honestly cannot recommend it if you're the kind of player who wants to play casual 1v1 matches online with customizable rules. You know, like in Smash. That's literally the only game mode I want to play. 1v1 casual matchmaking. Is it that fucking hard to implement? The closest things to that in this game are just some insanely annoying 4-player timed free-for-all mode, which is definitely not what I want to play, or RANKED 1v1 matchmaking, which (surprise surprise) isn't exactly a place where a first-timer could learn the game and have fun doing it. I was completely destroyed there, yet my rating only went down -15 from the default rating (1500 iirc?). So I'd have to get my ass handed to me like a hundred times before I'd get opponents my level.

I'm sure this game is fun in local couch multiplayer, or maybe even 2v2 online coop multiplayer with a friend. But for people without friends, just nah.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Yes, this is an SSB clone, but it's also much more than that. The game's fluid, gorgeous and satisfying. Also, it's free, so why don't at least give it a try? There aren't many different movesets, so it's not as hard to get into this one compared to other fighting games.

[h1]Brawlhalla![/h1]
I don't understand the hate towards this game. Yeah, it's an SSB clone, but it's on PC! Heck, it's even on mobile! Do you see SSB on PC? No? Well here you go!

Look, yeah, this game is not perfect. The networking can be a bit iffy at times and the focus on weapon movesets instead of character movesets makes the game feel a bit more samey. One could argue, however, that this is actually a positive, as learning the moveset of one character can transfer over to multiple other ones, making the learning curve significantly easier and helping new players understand the game.

Also, I don't think anyone will deny that this game is gorgeous - its animations are incredibly slick, its character design is top-notch, and many of the skins are great. During actual matches, fights look a lot like dances, as legends weave and parry each other. Most of the time, hitboxes feel fair and hits feel deserved. Very rarely do I get frustrated with the game (when I do, it's usually due to lag issues) - I mostly get frustrated at myself. It just seems like there's always room to improve with this game. It's great.

So yeah, I do recommend Brawlhalla. It's a polished, simpler version of Super Smash Brothers, available for free on PC, Mobile and consoles. If you like SSB and avoided this game thinking it's just an SSB clone, don't. Yeah, it's a clone. But it's also more than [i]just[/i] that.

Since this is a game I care about, I'll give it an honest review...

The first thing people say about Brawlhalla, is that it's basically a "Free version of Super Smash Bros."
I mean, it plays similarly to Smash (Given the premise/main goal is the same), but there's a few things that differenciate Brawlhalla from Smash.
For example; Some button inputs are different, combo strings are different, all neutral attacks are the same (depending on weapon type), the characters are more lovable (in my opinion), there's lore (if you care about that), and so much more...

With that out of the way...
It's one of those 'Easy to play, difficult to master' type deals, which severely hampers newcomers who are just starting out and learning the ropes.
If you play with your buddies, cool. You'll enjoy it. It's a fun way to kill a lot of time.
If you play online... you'll be put up against one of the most toxic playerbases known to planet Earth.
They will do anything to win. I'm often put up against spammers, cheaters or near-(if not) Pros.
To put it simply, 'Matchmaking' simply does not exist. (And do not even get me started on Ranked...)

Apart from unlocking Legends, you have to pay for *everything*.
Weapon skins, emojis, taunts, outfits, skins, colours...
I know the devs have to make their money. But the pricing is ridiculous...

Anyway. TL;DR:
Brawlhalla is a lot of fun, and it's easy to pick up and get good at.
On the other hand; The community is *very* toxic, and everything is rather expensive.
I recommend on gameplay alone.

After playing this game I now know why it's free. A company that over looks so many little details would never make money off of selling a game like this. It's fun, but that's sometimes ruined by bad hit boxes, not knowing what moves will over take what moves (because its entirely random and probably rng based), and huge openings in some of the characters basic attacks. If this game wasn't free it would be dead. Only thing saving it is the fun aspect of having a free 8 player brawl game that I can play on the PC. Overall if i had to choose between this game and Super Smash Bros this game is  pathetic in comparison. Great game for a seemly small company, but way too many small things over looked that shouldn't have been in a fighting game. Edit: I play this only with friends now, and still face the same problems game is only good because it's free.

Pay to win with unreasonable in-game currencies. (yes plural) Not to mention, the higher you progress, the more toxic the community gets. But you likely already figured that out. It's just not worth your time or money honestly.

If you're still reading, then it should be noted that they have things like country flags, sexuality flags, and gender identity flags all locked behind an in-game currency wall. Despite claiming to "support" said communities. And last time I checked support with conditions isn't actually support, because when you boil it down it just turns out to be a glorified bribe. 
So, if the developers are reading this, make flags and support emotes, flags, etc FREE for all players. THAT would be showing one's support towards a cause, not only is it the right thing to do but it's also just financially smart. Because at the end of the day it boils down to 2 things.
Players shouldn't have to pay to show our support for a cause, especially when they are things we can't change like place of birth or sexuality.
And, letting us show our beliefs or those we support like stated above, increases customer loyalty and purchases over time.

I've played this game for 831 hours. Never got above mid-gold. Today, I am putting the game down. I've always had a love hate relationship with this game and I tried my best to get better at it. However, the mechanics always make me give up. 
The straw that broke the camel's back today was the passive players. It's been however long since the last patch and it was supposed to encourage active play. But it seems that everyone I play takes the passive approach once they start losing and it just sucks the fun out of it for me. I was born in the 80s and grew up in an era where fighting games required skill and precision. Brawhalla requires some skill, but it feels like the developers have consistently been pushing the lines toward approachability to the point where anyone can pick up the game, pick an overpowered character, and have at it. Don't mind me. Just an old man yelling at the sky. I gave it an honest college try, but it's just not for me anymore.

Right off the bat i'm jumping into this cesspool of a game. From the store the game looks like a generic 2d fighting game with various attacks and combos, god was that a fucking decoy for the hell sitting behind it. First off you have 3 jumps a dodge, and the dodge can be used for even more distance depending on what character you pick. By the way practically all the characters are the same they all have basically the same weapons which is the same move set besides the signatures or the smash attacks. you might say oh but the stats of the characters is different so they are not even close the same. The different stats for the characters isn't wide enough for it to be looked at players with a serious eye unlike smash where each character is extremely unique to fit someones play style. This is only the surface of the problems of which Brawlhalla holds. But to someone who has played this game for 400 hours please do not play this god awful smash copy.

If you're a fan of bad netcode, hitboxes that are nothing like how they look and/or hitboxes that are much larger than they should be, character imbalance, terrible matchmaking, toxic gameplay, unbalanced weapons and cheap play, this game is for you.

If you want to win, pick up Orion. His specials are disgustingly fast and large, and he has little to no end lag on any of them. With the current state of the game being centered around waiting for someone to dodge, or try and get in anywhere, a lot of matches can lead to just standing around or idling away from eachother cross stage. When it comes to fighting Orion, I actually just wait for him to get bored. There's no getting in or out of a good Orion; so your best option is to just not play the game. 

With that in mind, any game where your only option is to not play the game, isn't worth playing alone in the first place. 
Only pick this up to play on a late night with friends. The competitive play of this game is sickening.

8- Pain, agony even, suffering if you will.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).
Lightly grease an 8-inch square baking pan with cooking oil spray. Line with parchment paper (or baking paper); set aside.
Combine hot melted butter, oil and sugar together in a medium-sized bowl. Whisk well for about a minute. Add the eggs and vanilla; beat until lighter in colour (another minute).
Sift in flour, cocoa powder and salt. Gently fold the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until JUST combined (do NOT over beat as doing so well affect the texture of your brownies).

Pour batter into prepared pan, smoothing the top out evenly. (OPTIONAL: Top with chocolate chunks or chocolate chips.)
Bake for 20-25 minutes, or until the centre of the brownies in the pan no longer jiggles and is just set to the touch (the brownies will keep baking in the hot pan out of the oven). If testing with a toothpick, the toothpick should come out dirty for fudge-textured brownies.
Remove and allow to cool to room temperature before slicing into 16 brownies.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

After playing this game for nearly 900 hours, and reaching high platinum for multiple seasons in a row. I can confirm the matchmaking system is still the worst I have seen in any game. I guarantee you that most of the games you will play will be with people ranked higher then you. I've just started playing recently again and I'm having trouble making it out of low gold. This is not because I've gotten rusty at the game but because the players I've been up against are people who have quite literally been ranked diamond in the previous seasons (checked using brawlhalla tracker). The matchmaking system has always been like this and the only guaranteed way to progress through the ranks is either being extremely lucky, or by being as good as the diamond players you are fighting. In Brawlhalla it's either you get 3 stocked or you 3 stock them, this leads to boring game play sessions because you're only playing with players far worse, or far better then you. This game would be a thousand times better playing against people your own skill level.

Old Fashioned Pumpkin Pie

2 large eggs
1 large egg yolk
1/2 cup packed dark brown sugar
1/3 cup white sugar
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 teaspoons cinnamon
1 teaspoon ground ginger
1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg
1/4 teaspoon ground cloves
1/8 teaspoon cardamom
1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest
2 cups pumpkin purée from a sugar pumpkin (see Recipe Note) OR 1 (15-ounce can) pumpkin purée (can also use puréed cooked butternut squash)
1 1/2 cups heavy cream or 1 (12-ounce) can evaporated milk
1 homemade pie crust, chilled or frozen (see pâte brisée recipe or our no-fail flaky pie crust recipe), or 2 pre-made pie shells

Preheat the oven:
Preheat your oven to 425°F.
Make the filling:
Beat the eggs in a large bowl. Mix in the brown sugar, white sugar, salt, spices — cinnamon, ground ginger, nutmeg, ground cloves, cardamom, and lemon zest.
Mix in the pumpkin purée. Stir in the cream. Beat together until everything is well mixed.
mixing pumpkin pie ingredients
pumpkin pie ingredients mixed well
adding cream to pumpkin pie puree
pumpkin pie filling ready to add to pie
Fill the pie shell and bake:
Pour the filling into an uncooked chilled or frozen pie shell. Bake at a high temperature of 425°F for 15 minutes.
Then after 15 minutes, lower the temperature to 350°F. Bake for 45 to 55 minutes more. The pie is done when a knife tip inserted in the center comes out wet but relatively clean. The center should be just barely jiggly.
(About half-way through the baking, you may want to put foil around the edges or use a pie protector to keep the crust from getting too browned.)
Note that the pumpkin pie will come out of the oven all puffed up (from the leavening of the eggs), and will deflate as it cools.
pumpkin pie in dish ready for baking
Baked Pumpkin Pie From Scratch
Cool the pie on a rack, then serve:
Cool the pumpkin pie on a wire rack for 2 hours.
Serve with whipped cream.

This game is amazing! 50+ legends to pick gives me a lot of strategies and unique gameplay! It can be pretty hard to learn every character and how to play the whole game in general, but when you do, it feels great! My favorite character is Rayman, a legend that uses Gauntlets and Axe as his weapons. He's the first of many characters to collaborate with Brawlhalla and it's a great first choice! I HIGHLY recommend this game because it's free and there's a lot of competition and replayability! Even though there's a crap ton of microtransactions, you can still play without them!

It's easy to play with and without players. There is one optimal weapon which is the scythe, using this weapon to deal dmg than signature move to kill your opponent will always be the meta. Dodges are seemingly infinite which is why scythe is so good because even if you dodge they will continue to tic your bar away. Game punishes the attacker so passive play is the optimal play, that is, not playing at all until attacked. EVEN then its about poking and running away so you can be passive and wait for a attack again. Stay away unless you just want to play your friends in a PvP platformer game

The game is good but only for beginners/newbies to fighting games. If you came from smash or other such games then you will be disappointed by the lack of depth in the game as the mechanics include dashing but not much more. However, it is a game that is easy to play (kinda like LoL) with the matches being >8 mins long and it is pretty easy to get into a match (usually takes >1 min to get into a match).
My other problem with the game is that the characters are not very unique as in their abilities may be different but the light attacks are all the same (given its the same weapon) and spamming the special abilities is a big issue. Though you may have heard that the character are all 'balanced' some characters are simply broken as they just spam their abilities with obscene reach and double hits(so even if you dodge once you cant dodge the second attack). 

Overall, Its a good game for casual play and the fact that its cross-play and free help.

If you're a PC gamer who's thirsty for some Super Smash Bros.-style action, direct your parched eyes at Brawlhalla. The platform-based fighting game tasks you with fighting up to three opponents on floating stages, and attempting to knock them off the platform to score points. Directional inputs change your fighter's attacks, but much like Smash, the character movesets are relatively easy to learn.

Brawlhalla has a standardized set of weapons (with signature moves being the only difference) that are assigned to characters permanently, and playable characters are rotated every week, though you can purchase your favorite characters using the in-game currency.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 18 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

Brawlhalla is a free-to-play fighting game developed by Blue Mammoth Games and published by Ubisoft for macOS, Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Nintendo Switch, Xbox One, Xbox Series S & X, Android and iOS, with full cross-play across all platforms. The game was shown at PAX East in April 2014, and went into alpha later that month. An open beta became available in November 2015, followed by the game's release in October 2017. As of March 2022, the game features 55 playable characters called "Legends", each with their own unique stats, loadout, and available cosmetic skins.

Hello, casual player here. The game itself is well done, lots of different characters, while having simple mechanics and, from my limited experience, a good online community, at least out of the game. 

The in-game interactions though, oh boy. Sometimes people will curse you, sometimes they will be wholesome, and to accept an invitation to a custom game room (where there is the possibility to converse freely) feels like a game of russian roulette, especially after 1v1 games. You'll never know what they'll write to you, and there is a concrete possibility that some people will insult you on the basis of every little information they can gather from your profile, avatar picture, or even play-style (come on, guys, play-style?); among the not-so-few bad apples I met xenophobic, transphobic, homophobic, and a whole range of verbally violent people.
Every time I accept to talk to somebody, I really hope it's not one of those cases: it's not like that over half of those times, and it feels good to have a proper conversation or to play another couple of games in all tranquility, but when the worst case scenario happens... I feel awful.
Regrettably this strikes close to my heart, and I prefer to keep this type of negative interactions to a minimum, so my advice for myself would be to not install this game, I'm better off without all the drama that comes with it.

My review stays positive because the game is good, the developers are fantastic, super fun to play with friends, and it's probably for people who have a thicker skin than I do, but I hope that in the future players will change for the better.

This game is free AND fun. You can button mash, or study frame data and combos and enjoy it either way. Plus there are a lot of people playing online, and open tournaments.

This game honestly has just gone so downhill. When I used to play it back in late 2018-2019, I was enjoying myself. The game was fast-paced, diversity in weapons and characters in queue, all of it. But now the devs don't seem to know how to balance their game without causing another problem. Sure, balancing fighting games is not an easy task but in this game, some weapons are just straight up better than others and the gameplay has just slowed down so much. I wish I could love this game the way I used to but unfortunately, it's not the game it once was.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead– murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time – something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange – uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" – on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family.

Very fun and addicting game, but obviously there are areas of improvement. 
1. The rocket lance is simply stupid. Yes, I know the weapon isn't frequently used in high tier, but the weapon statistically has the highest win rate out of all weapons (51.91% win rate according to brawlmance.com), meaning at least in silver, gold and maybe low platinum, where most of the player base is in, the weapon is frequently used and drawing out high win rates. While there maybe debates on whether the lance is overpowered or not, it is undeniable that it is a weapon that ruins the experience of the game due to its ridiculous weapon mechanism and hitbox that counters almost every weapon in silver ~ gold. Many of my friends that have started the game with me also have expressed complaints about the lance ruining their experience with brawlhalla. I believe the rocket lance needs a rework (especially in terms of hitbox) so it is more balanced both in low and high tiers. 
2. There are a lot of passive players that simply earn so much from waiting out the entire game and playing like a total pu$$y. This issue also has to be addressed asap. 
3. If the rocket lance is not suitable for a rework, deleting the weapon as a whole and making a new weapon for previous rocket lance legends also may be a good idea because the weapon is beyond the limits of being stupid. 

Very fun and high quality for a free game though, I recommend people to give it a try :)

Buen juego, entretenido para pasar el rato, buena variabilidad de armas y movimientos, buena diversidad de modos de juego. 

COSAS A MEJORAR:

-Deberían sacar leyendas más frecuentemente. Estaría muy bueno que saquen una leyenda por mes o cada dos meses. Obviamente supone trabajo el hecho de crear un personaje nuevo, pero creo que podrían llegar.

-Lamentablemente no hay maneras de conseguir skins que no sean con dinero real, por lo que estaría muy bueno que se puedan desbloquear skins aleatorias de algún modo. Lo que a mí se me ocurrió fue lo siguiente: Si ganas un juego sin morir ni una sola vez, consigues un fragmento de cofre de skin. Con cierta cantidad de fragmentos (5 por ejemplo), puedes abrir un cofre que te da una skin aleatoria. Y que solo se pueda conseguir un fragmento por leyenda por season. Es decir, si yo conseguí un fragmento con Nix, no puedo conseguir otro fragmento con esa misma leyenda hasta la siguiente season.

-Que se puedan conseguir colores de pases de batalla anteriores. Que durante un pase de batalla se agregue un cofre que cuesta una buena cantidad de oro (15.000 o más) que al abrirlo de un color dé un pase de batalla anterior para una leyenda aleatoria.

This game has so much content to offer for a free PvP fighting game. Not only is it an outstanding party game but it has such great communities worldwide and even paid tournaments! A vast variety of heroes to choose from to brawl with and different weapon types to make every game different and interesting. I paid $15 for ALL of the heroes but I regret doing so now seeing that ill be dumping an immense amount of my time into this incredibly well developed game. The best comparison is PC Super Smash Brothers, although it may not be Smash Bros it does have a lot of crossovers like Street Fighter, Adventure Time and The Walking Dead. In my opinion, this game is 9/10. Only thing that can make it better is the constant addition of content, its thriving communities to thrive harder and for the devs to keep doing their thing! I was told about this game by a co-worker. Great game to get some Super Smash Brothers nostalgia. After a good chunk of hours you realize it is it's own game and more competitive and strategic.

After 25 hours I started doing ranked with my friend and we are getting stuck around high silver. There are some sweaty players so be ready for some pain and misery. By your next game you end up dominating and it boosts your moral. All in all I highly recommend this game. You can't go wrong with a free game that takes up only 1gb of disk space that gives you hours of fun. Casual or Hardcore this game is for everyone.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead– murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time – something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange – uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" – on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

'Yumburger' -Ghandi

Jolliebee's Yum Burger with Cheese features a beef patty with cheese and their "special burger dressing" on a soft burger bun.

Jolliebee's Yum Burger with Cheese features a beef patty with cheese and their "special burger dressing" on a soft burger bun. Jolliebee's is a fast food chain from the Philippines so you can consider it a Filipino take on American fast food.

While the Yum burger seems pretty familiar on paper and in appearance, it's definitely different from American burgers.

First off the patty itself is heavily seasoned compared to say McDonald's or Wendy's and had a nicely charred crust. While the Jollibee website doesn't list the ingredients of the beef patty, copycat recipes suggest that it's seasoned with onion powder and MSG in addition to the typical salt and pepper. It didn't taste like any seasoned burger I've had. It wasn't bad though, just different.

The cheese was weird. It didn't quite melt into a goo so much as a goo with granules in it. The taste was a bit bland but okay.

Rather than ketchup or mustard, Jolliebee's special sauce seems to be a sweeter, creamy mayo and they do not skimp on it. I get the feeling that their home market must really like the mayo. It was a lot too much for me though.

The bun was the most familiar component and was squishy soft and airy.

Overall, eating Jolliebee's Yum burger with cheese was an interesting experience and worth a try if you're curious, but I wouldn't get it again (mostly due to the weird cheese and excessive mayo although I suppose you can ask for less).

This game is really fun. People think it's a Super Smash ripoff, and it may have started as one, but it has blossomed into a great game.

     There are over 50 different characters to play as, and they all have their unique signature moves. The game is very movement heavy, with proper positioning being incredibly important, especially at high ranks.

     The only issues are the balancing and some aspects of the gameplay; the meta changes a lot and that can impact your performance a lot. Because of an overpowered dodge system, it's easy to run away, which can get stale fast.

Other than those points, the game is engaging and kind of addicting. 9/10

Pros: 
-Lightweight
-Runs on everything
-fast paced
-tons of game modes to play
-you can be casual or sweat
-mods (for pc)
-really nice people and easy way to make friends
-tons of characters and playstyles for you to play and master.

Cons:
-in recent years the meta has gotten stale and boring and as of 03/13/2022 axe has needed a serious nerf, and it hasn't gotten one. That has bled into competitive play where gods of this game are being destroyed by day 1 axe true combos. please bmg do something. lol
-the anti cheat makes the game run like poopy
-i'd say toxic community but i have participated myself so i'd be a hypocrite complaining about it. be nice to each other!!
-not ALL crossover skins, but some have animations that need updating because as of right now they have a leg up on the actual character they represent (ie. Val -> stevonnie/akuma, thatch - storm shadow)

overall this is one of my favorite fighters of all time and favorite games. I recommend it to everybody, but none of my friends play it. LOL

This game is really good for what I use it for. I play the game to have fun in customs with my friends. That being said, the meta and the current state of the game is abysmal. Hammer and Axe are meant to be heavy, but are fast and do twice as much damage. On top of that, you lose if you engage so games go forever and 2 players are left sitting on either side of the stage waiting to engage. You can win by sig spamming lord vraxx at a much higher level than just gold, and everything is countered by teros. This game is really fun for casual players, but don't think about playing a competitive level because it's stale and boring.

Honestly, this game used to be a love/hate relationship. It was an addiction for a long time, however the last 4 months. I've felt no desire to play this game anymore. I absolutely cannot stand the devs/ community. They don't care about this game nor their player base in any sort of way. They just release new skins every month to grab more of your money. I've spent a lot of money on this game and put a lot of my time into it. I'm finally quitting because no matter how many people speak up about the balance issues, things that need to be changed/ introduced. They do nothing and just release new skins. They nerf the wrong weapons, buff the weapons that were balanced. Change things that didn't need to be changed. The devs just rotate the meta around for each tournament to spice up the game play. There are so many things wrong about this game that could be improved/ fixed if they would just listen to their player-base. Like for example, the weapon throws/ reward for playing super passive ( and by passive, I don't mean playing smart and adapting to your opponents play style. I mean literally just running and waiting the entire game), etc. I know I'm not the only one that feels this way either. Would I have recommended this game in the past? Absolutely, it was different from other platform fighting games and a lot of fun. Would I recommend this game currently? no, I personally have gotten everything I wanted out of this game a long time ago and I only see it going down hill from here. It's just a big money grab. Maybe i'll revisit it in the future if things change. I doubt that will ever happen though. GG shit game

I’ll start off this review by saying 2 things. If you want a game to waste time on or just something to mindlessly play, this game is for you. If you have a short temper or take games too seriously, this game is most certaintly not for you. 
You should definitely at least give the game a try, because it free. But the reason im leaving a negative review is because im using the terms of “would you recommend this game?” I wouldn’t. The community is god awful, and the balancing in this game is almost as bad. Don’t play this, play another fighting game. If you’re looking at the reviews of a free game, and are reading this negative review, then something inside you is saying that the game isn’t worth your time. Listen to that voice.

It's a generic free to play fighting game with lazy developers. Ranked is full of toxic players who either should't be in that rank (weather it's because they suck more than you or you suck a lot more than them), no one plays 4p free for all except for total beginners, and experimental is just ranked without numbers indicating your rank.

Now I wouldn't mind all of that. Toxic players exist, bad rank mechanics exist. It's nothing unusual, but at the same time, the game uses an adobe animation program as a game engine (almost). Most of the animations are made by draging and reshaping predrawn limbs. Only signature attacks are hand drawn, and even they are only partially hand drawn. This is called lazy as you can just redraw every limb and done, you have a new character.

New characters for some reason tend to be unbalanced for the first month of existence (probably to boost their popularity), skins aren't worth the money (Considering anyone can just redraw the limbs and done, new skin is made)

Rankings are bad, the game's netcode is bad, multiplayer is bad, it's free to play so the annoying toxic kids without money have full access to it. Bmg is literally owned by Ubisoft. Why don't they give them budget to make a solid game with good mechanics and actually fully hand drawn animations?

Make the characters unique. So unique that starting a new character would feel like starting the game from scratch. This is a lazy free to play project that isn't finished. I'm off to play SkullGirls.

There are three types of men in this world. Men with standards. Men who can't afford Smash + Nintendo's internet tax. Lastly, men that play Brawlhalla voluntarily. Don't trust men that play Brawlhalla voluntarily. Don't even look them in the eye.

This game has grotesque art direction which exudes the esthetic essence of a cheap Newgrounds Flash game, but with none of the charm. Legends are mass produced through a tragic template consisting of ugly thick forearms, sausage fingers, Chernobylian shins, and oversized heads. They all look simply terrible. Except for a rock golem called Kor. God bless Kor. The fighting stages are unamusing, ranging from non-descript cultural landmark to generic location from ambiguous point in time. This monotonous selection hinders replayability.

The game plays with the floatiness of a helium-filled balloon. It discourages aggressive play and encourages passive, tedious fights. Encourages spam. Takes a [i]quantity over quality[/i] approach to characters, with all characters sharing the same basic size and moves.

All earnable content is a tedious grind. Nearly all earnable cosmetics are pathetic. Nearly all
 worth-while cosmetics are locked behind microtransations.

The premise takes place in Valhalla, where a tournament pits legends from history against each other. Despite having a serviceable, hard-to-fuck-up premise, it is very well wasted in it's execution. In an attempt to compete with the 72-count arsenal of characters Smash has to offer, the game creates a bloated cast of generic, one-dimensional stereotypes and increasingly monotone expositions of origin that no one cares about. Further crippled with desperate promotional bloat; advertisements for all matters of good and terrible cartoons, movies, and shows. With great characters such as ordinary fit guy from fight show, and random bloke (from show that lost relevance 5-10 years ago and as a result is mass-licensing to maintain some level of relevance) along side the likes of Thor, God of Thunder and the Legendary Warrior Orion. You know, characters with historical precedence and mythological importance.

This game is made to sell stuff to you, not to be enjoyed as a game.

My personal experience with Brawl is 95% private lobbies with friends or family. So I cannot speak for online play as I've only experienced it in very short bursts. But overall, Brawlhalla is a good little Smash Brothers-esque fighting game. A huge collection of unique characters and crossover characters give you no shortage of niches to choose from and experiment with. I'm personally an Orion/Brynn/Asuri/Zariel player.

I should definitely warn you that you have to individually purchase these "Legends" (the Brawlhalla term for characters) with ingame coin, though. Not too bad. But the game does offer you the option to buy access to every legend. Both present and future releases, will always be open to you. Otherwise, the game does rotations to let you try out 9 random legends, every week.

The gameplay is quite fun and action packed. Your weapon type highly effects your moveset and hitboxes, so you'll have to learn your character's moveset and weapons very well in order to be accurate as splash damage and other types of damage besides pinpoint accuracy (it's not quite that bad but still) are not a factor and you will miss repeatedly if you don't aim and time your moves correctly. Each character is also equipped with different stats. So you have tanky, slower builds and faster, lightweigh builds. Despite this, the game does a very good job at keeping things balanced and for the most part, it all comes down to player skill and experience at least 98% of the time.
Definitely a fun time, especially with a group of friends playing in couch mode!

Massa do Bolo
3 cenouras médias (250g)
4 ovos
meia xícara (chá) de óleo
2 e meia xícaras (chá) de farinha de trigo
2 xícaras (chá) de açúcar
1 colher (sopa) de fermento em pó
Cobertura de Brigadeiro
1 Leite MOÇA® (lata ou caixinha) 395g
1 colher (sopa) de manteiga
meia xícara (chá) de Chocolate em Pó NESTLÉ® DOIS FRADES®
meia xícara (chá) de chocolate granulado
Modo de preparo
Massa do Bolo
Em um liquidificador, bata as cenouras, os ovos e o óleo.

Despeje a mistura em um recipiente e misture o açúcar e a farinha de trigo peneirada com o fermento.

Coloque em uma fôrma retangular (20 x 30 cm) untada, e leve ao forno médio (180°C), preaquecido, por 40 minutos.

Enquanto isso, prepare a cobertura de brigadeiro.

Cobertura de Brigadeiro
Em uma panela coloque o Leite MOÇA, o Chocolate em Pó DOIS FRADES e a manteiga e leve ao fogo baixo, mexendo sempre, até começar a desprender da panela.

Despeje ainda quente sobre o bolo, distribua o chocolate granulado e deixe esfriar.

Ive never felt so conflicted about a game. Like, as a game its top notch. Ive had fun doing literally everything the game has to offer. The game play is tight, the game runs well, you can tell the game is made with real care and detail. There are things in this game ive never seen in an mmorpg and just a general level of creativeness that genuinely impressed me. The boss fights are an absolute blast and, again, had some basic but creative mechanics that surprised me in the best way.

Then...the elephant in the room. Lets cut the ♥♥♥♥. The games progression pathway is designed to suck you in. Resources are plentiful. Upgrades fire off without failing. Your personal damage grows MASSIVELY fast after hitting 50 it feels so damn good. However, the farther you get the more you can see plain as day that the systems are designed to frustrate you enough to get you to pay. You run out of readily available resources and have to farm it out but your upgrades are failing now. You put all that work into farming up a pile of resources you might just lose all of if you are unlucky. This game is designed to take all of your time to play optimally and then spit it back in your face to try and get you to pay. The entire loot cycle is just time consuming and the game has no respect for your time. Their only interest is your wallet. They get you hooked early on with how easy it is, how much power you gain, then they stick it to you hard and its honestly predatory.

So do I recommend this game? Its a great game. I loved every minute of my time here, even the story (I dont think its as bad as some would lead you to believe) BUT this is an MMO. A game genera designed to get you invested and keep you their long term. With how loot upgrades works...I just cant bring myself to recommend the game. Its good, ill always play it casually but this will never be a "Main MMO" just simply because I dislike wasting my time and this game will ♥♥♥♥ all over your time and kick you in the ass until your credit card falls out.

Definitely a fun game that would suit a variety of players.

You can have casual fun for a while, but where you're gonna put in 100s of hours is when you start playing competitively. The roster and playstyles are diverse and challenging enough to keep you motivated. 

However, once you start getting close as a high tier player, things start becoming monotonous. You've got just about every character and weapon combo down, but now playing casually is frustrating because winning either becomes a routine or a frustrating hassle as the game is filled with more casuals that use an annoying play style. The competitive scene is frustrating as well because of toxic players or simply not enough enticement to continue in ranked. Unless you start going to tournaments, a completionist/perfectionist, or someone with a god complex that likes to curb stomp on noobs, there is no reason to attempt reaching diamond. Gold is about where most casual, somewhat competitive players end up and it is a frustrating middle ground in casual 2v2 lobbies: you either get paired up with complete noobs and lose or get matched against a team of hardcore competitive players and get dominated.

I clearly have a lot of hours on this game so if you are trying to see what this is all about with all the multiversus hype let me clue you in. The balance team is god-awful and constantly needx hotfixes but rarely does anything to solve the problems within the game. For example when you first start out if you can get through the first 50 hours of learning the game and learning to get past the spammers or just becoming a spammer yourself(that's another problem by the way, the playerbase) then you will need to actually learn the game. Now you get past that and you are immediately slapped in the face by the development team who cares about nothing besides artwork(the artwork is fantastic) and will make the most broken, pay to win, crossovers that will either have completely silent moves or moves that are just straight up faster than what they normally are with different visuals. I truly would not recommend this game to new players just play multiversus.

Brawl, Brawl is a fun game with friends. I have a ♥♥♥♥ ton of memories of me and my friends playing this game, we would do all the different game modes and have a blast. Me and my friends started doing rank and let me tell you something it was fun, it was a blast and I enjoyed it. 2v2 rank was great, it lead to many funny moments and inside jokes. Sadly I can't recommend this game anymore. It was nice back before scythe was added, after that the characters started to become less fun and feel like they were running out of ideas. they even made 1 character so Identical to another that when I first say someone play I thought it was a skin. Its sad because this game has so much potential but instead of adding on to the simple moves and combos they started making them way more complex, and complexity isnt always good. Don't even get me started on the community, its so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ toxic and I don't know if it was me but the game also made me toxic. It was unfun at times because of its Bs moves like the scythe. People either spammed moves and you either kept getting hit or dodged and just win with no challenge. I feel like this game was going to the right direction but after they started to add characters and weapons that didn't fit the style of the game then thats when everything started going down, I started to have less fun and started to get more toxic. this game is nice the moves are simple to learn, the combos are easy to do but they are all hard to master. Learning spacing and all that comes with a fighting game but brawlhalla was fun because its simplicity really did make it go the extra mile. Ill give you an example, I played brawl and at first I was really bad at it, like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ garbage. my friends would demolish me but I still had fun. ONLY a few months went by and I was already better then most of my friends. now lets take a different game, csgo one that I put around the same hours into (300+) and when I first started I sucked ass, a few months later I still sucked ass, I still can't beat my friends in a 1v1. Brawl was simplistic and it was fun, now the game has tried to become more complex but instead made it more toxic and cancer with unfun combos and unfun weapons.

By far the worst game i have ever played. It is unbalanced af and most problems like balancing and bugs will never get fixed because the developers don't give a damn about the community and the things they are complaining about.
They managed to remove the post gamechat, which should tell you enough that these people just like to take the lazy route instead of adding a much requested toggle option.
The battlpasses are just a quick cash grab and made in such a way that completing the missions is just not fun at all. These missions basically just tell you to spam the signature button a lot to get kills.
Half of the payed track is filled with cosmetic colours. You will always unlock a colour for one legend only, but you don't get to choose which one because it is random. so when you're lucky, you will have to complete the obligatory battlepass mission that tells you to play or win games with a legend that has this new colour equipped, with a legend you don't even like. The games you have to play can range up to an insufferable amont of games.
To top it all off, at the end of the pass you will unlock the colours for every legend and future legend to come. In conclusion, half of the battlepass is just air.
Some missions even tell you to go play ranked and just expect you to win. Because playing ranked is a fun experience for everybody.
To get the full value out of the battle pass, you will have to complete every mission.
Matchmaking in this game is ass.It will either pair you with someone who is much better or much worse. Basically either you get 3 stocked or your opponent gets 3 stocked but nothing in between.
Some weapons or legends in this game just translate into an instant win. 
Passive behaviour gets rewarded by the game.
servers are trash.
And finally i would like to know why starting up a 2D 200Mb game takes so fricking long???

Jokes aside, I've been overdo on reviewing all the games I own.

I admit I like the various and different character designs, you can tell they put work into designing every legend to be as unique as possible from each other: 
But at the same time that's my major gripe with the game: Is unlocking the gold blocked content. It's insidiously hard to grind for every legend you want or luck out and buy them when they drop in price. 
Over all the game is entirely solid but it's not a game I'd ever want to play competitively because it feels, well, too simple? I play with people in plat and gold, and it's pretty obvious just learning strings and your fundamentals is absolutely key to being any good. Also have you seen some of the things nerds type in ranked chat? More toxic than plutonium. 

Regardless, I still enjoy the game for the social element and meme potential, plus I admit I've had fun stream sniping lobbies

This game gives you many mixed feelings.  It's like a toxic relationship that you need to let go of but you just never can.  And that's the lightest way I can put it.   Here's some pro's and con's

Pros: 
- Comic/animated Graphics
- Smooth move transitions and game-play (Provided you have good internet)
- A multitude of characters to choose from, with about 6+ different weapons and moves for each character
- Great sound effects with a decent soundtrack as well
- Tons of skins and a battle pass ( If you think that's a con I would understand, But they need the money)

Cons:
- The hit-boxes can be weird at times
- A lot of the player base is veterans, so even if you just started the game, you may get dogged on by people whom have lowered their rank for easier play
- Skilled based match making so prepare to sweat
- A pretty intense grind for characters and basic colors/ skins (unless you buy the full character pack or your own skins)

Overall I love this toxic experience.  One moment you go from absolutely destroying someone.  To being absolute dog water, and wanting to break your keyboard in half.  Yes i have thrown my mouse several times.  Yes it has the same idea as super smash, NO IT IS NOT THE SAME.   You have so many jumps and opportunities to get back on the platform, it is insane.  Definitely check the game out though, you will not be disappointed.   Some moments you'll love this game, and most of the time you will scream at the screen and curse the other player while they use the laugh emoji a bunch of times.   Yes, you can either do a couch party with your friends or through online/LAN.  They also have a "Ranked mode" and many other fun game modes.  Like I said, you win, get hyped, then lose a bunch, then quit.  But hey, you eventually come back and try again.  Because after all, this game just has a whole different and amazing feel to winning.     Hopefully this helps, leave a like if it did.

I would like to preface this by saying two important things: Firstly, that I often prefer singleplayer games over battle royale/multiplayer battle games like this. Secondly, I do enjoy this game. Brawlhalla is a wonderful game that simulates the tense gameplay of the better-known Super Smash Bros. series, and does it for free. Additionally. In my experience, the game is far more balanced than Super smash bros. I mean this in the sense that any character can often have an advantage over another with enough technique, and combo-attacks that are impossible to dodge or avoid are incredibly sparse. Brawlhalla achieves this equilibrium by creating uniform weapons that every character must use, as well as reducing the strength of individual attacks to encourage the use of many attacks in quick succession. I do enjoy these mechanics, and I would even go so far as to say it is a better play experience than the Super Smash Bros. games. That said, I'm assuming you're wondering why I labeled this review as negative. This is because an incredibly important issue with not only the game but the entire genre it belongs to. Brawlhalla is by far the best multiplayer battler I have ever played, Far surpassing multiplayer modes of games like Destiny 2, For example, playing Brawlhalla for long amounts of time will earn you coins which you can spend for different colors to a character. This is a way of showing off how much you've grown throughout your Brawlhalla experience, with black/goldforged being the highest prestige colors available. However, you can never truly reach a peak of ability as there are thousands of people far more experienced in this game. This is most certainly not a negative thing, as all multiplayer battlers have this caveat. However, the onslaught of salt-spewing kids and 'disrespecters' who attempt to defeat a player in the most humiliating way possible can feel really defeating. I would say that this can be cured by playing more and gaining a better understanding of the characters, but this gameplay isn't what I would call 'fun.' Learning the characters, or 'grinding,' as I would call it, is often comprised of the dishonerable fellows mentioned earlier, and that means that even training can be a challenge to your mental health. I will finish this review by saying that, with everything mentioned here, I will still play Brawlhalla with friends from time to time. The main factor in my decision to give a negative review is this: I feel that the past 200 hours of brawlhalla have well and truly been a waste of my time. after 200 hours, I am still bullied by the dishonerable fellows and it is simply not something that uplifts me. Would I reccommend someone to try out this game, to see how cool its mechanics are? probably yes! However, I cannot in good conscience encourage it as a 'fun game,' as gameplay can feel pretty cold and heartless the more you play. If you'll excuse me, I'm off to play a singleplayer game. Best of luck to future brawlers, and remember that you're awesome no matter what anyone says online!

As a person who is nearing 1000 hours in this game, I need to format my review in this way. I have had a fun time playing this game, and I have spent over 700 hours trying to hit gold rank. Unfortunately, I have not had any luck on that end. Regardless, this game is for anyone who likes to play platform fighters. The game is free and is on pretty much every device imaginable (current gen and previous gen). This game is able to be played casually as well as competitively, as I really enjoy relaxing and playing with my friends in a custom room. You can play more than 20 different game modes and the roster is always expanding, continuously giving you new ways to play. Unfortunately you only start out with 7 characters from the roster, but worry not as you do not have to spend real money on most of the cast. You can unlock the characters just by playing the game, which is a rewarding task in and of itself. Please consider trying out the experience that is Brawlhalla!

I think it was a decade ago when I played dungeon blitz on facebook and found out that it was taken down.
I followed the creators of the game till they released brawlhalla, which at time I thought was bad, simply because I kept falling off the platform and dying without being able to do much on laptop, hitting all the keys out of rage and uninstalling the game, hating the developers for taking down dungeon blitz, a game that I really loved for a stupid fighting game. Now after all those years I downloaded the game again and started 
playing it and guess what. I really like it, it's definitely one of the best casual games that are not heavy on specs, not p2w and possesses well thought out system, if there was problem then it's the learning curve and poor matchmaking, don't get me wrong it's fun destroying people 1v2 but really the treatment of new players is just poor in this game and that's why the overall score of this game is 9/10. 
Honestly I still prefer dungeon blitz, I loved summoning my purple minotaur to fight for me and
upgrading it to golden one touched my heart and made me so happy that I still have clear image of how it looked after all those years.
I recommend you to casually play this, do daily quests, join a clan, participate in events sometime and play ranked if you wanna take things a step further.
Good luck, adventurers.

This is great game to play with friends because of the offline modes and "couch party" play option that's great for when you just want to play with friends. This game is a bit different from SSBU, as it has different game mechanics and isn't just a blatant rip off of SSBU (which many people think). The real difference that sets this game apart from the rest is that it has a variety of online modes, a number of different skins for your characters, and just better multiplayer in general. 
The Pros;
- Great Multiplayer Game Modes 
- The Cool Skins
- Easy to pick up combat system
- Its variety of offline modes 
- Its ability to cross-play with other platforms
Cons; 
- Its Simplicity
- The fact that you have to buy skins and can't just earn them
The fact that this game is free is crazy. Anyone who is reading this should pick this game up. It's fun, easy to learn, and rewarding to master.

You might have come for a Brawlhalla review, but here's a brownie recipe
You will need - two eggs + a bit of water, powdered sugar, unsweetened cocoa powder, oil, flour, slat, and half a teaspoon of vanilla extract.
First, combine the sugar, flour, powdered sugar, cocoa powder, (If you want them) chocolate chips, and salt into a medium sized bowl. Then, whisk together the eggs, olive oil, and water in a large one.
Next, combine the wet and dry ingredients. Sprinkle the dry mixture over the wet one, and fold until just combined. The batter will be thick.
Then, pour the batter into an 8x8 inch baking pan lined with parchment paper. use a rubber spatula to spread it to all four sides of the pan and to smooth the top. The mixture will be very thick - that's OK.
Finally, bake! Transfer the pan to a 325-degree oven and bake for 40 to 45 minutes, until a toothpick inserted comes out with a few crumbs attached. Allow the brownies to cool completely before slicing and serving. Enjoy!
Recipe found on https://www.loveandlemons.com/brownies-recipe/

Yes this is a fun game to play casually and ranked ,but there are some players you have to look out for. The main players you have to look out for are Meta-Hoppers which only play the characters that are Meta and Spammers you should know what those are if you play fighting games. The main two meta characters that you have to watch out for are Teros a bull and Mordex a Werewolf other than that the ranked is fun. The Developers do release battle-passes the battle-passes you buy for real cash and finish with real cash changed into in game currency called Mammoth Coins, and skins you can buy with real money that is transferred into in Mammoth Coins but not an essential part of the game they just make you standout more. There are a lot of thing you can buy with the other in game currency called gold which you earn by playing matches of Casual or ranked. This allows you to buy legends that are not on the weakly legend rotation. Playing ranked and winning gives you Elo which and the end of the Ranked season will be changed to glory which you can use to buy things in the ranked shop. Before you label it as a Super Smash bros clone try this game out ,but hey I can't make your opinion for you. Just try it out and see if you like it. Have fun. At the time of typing this it is currently ranked season 22 and Battle-Pass season 5.
P.S. Don't be ass in game.

Indian Style Butter Chicken :)

(1) Add the ginger, garlic and green chilli in a wet grinder and blend to a smooth paste. Mix the yoghurt with the gram flour in a bowl to get rid of any lumps to form a thick paste like consistency. Add the ginger, garlic chilli paste, paprika, chilli powder, garam masala (which is a hot spice mixture, usually of ground coriander, cumin, cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, and pepper) . Also mix in the ground cinnamon, saffron and salt. Stir well and tip in the chicken pieces and mix well making sure to coat them in the thick marinade. Leave to marinate for a few hours or even overnight if you prefer. This can even be done a few hours in advance. 

(2) Once the chicken is cooked set aside and proceed to make the makhani sauce below. Heat a heavy bottom sauce pan and add the butter. Add green cardamom, cinnamon stick and cloves. Fry for 20 seconds, add the onions and sauté for 5-7 mins on medium heat until they take on a light brown colour.

(2) Add the grated ginger and slit green chillies. Fry for a further minute and add the chilli powder, garam masala powder along with the tomato puree. Stir well and cook for a couple of minutes. Now gradually add the double cream stirring continuously to mix all the spices with the cream. Simmer and cook for 2-3 minutes.

(3) At this stage add a splash of water if the curry is too thick. Stir in the honey and the fenugreek powder. Season to taste. Now add the cooked chicken pieces and simmer the curry on a low heat for 8-10 minutes. Garnish with coriander and serve with Indian style bread roti or parantha.

Issues : 
1) Lag as hell, usually i can watch 10 streams while playing other online games but this struggles often while not using anything else that needs an internet connection.
2) Spam??? Sure thing beginners just spam heavies all day but you can dodge them, right? And then you might play against someone that knows the game but they know combos with their weapons which even if you dodge they just continue to "spam" their combos and you don't have not just a change to win but a change to PLAY the game.
3) Lag input or what they call it. Simply put you press button and it delays to perform the action. Usually with the dodge mechanic, ie you try to dodge their combo but well it fails to dodge, what can you do.

Tips on how to have FUN :
1) I  guess you can have fun if you know how to do against the spam and the combos and also how to do combos as well. So you have to spend HOURS aside from gameplay to become better to PLAY a game. Well if you need to work on it and you think it is interesting by all means feel free to have fun. As for the internet issues i believe there's something happening with the game/servers although it doesn't happen that often usually 3/15 games or something.

So my opinion is that brawlhalla is a way to get tilted , of course i had fun playing with friends and on my own but at the end of the day the only feeling that remains is that of annoyance.

Basic moves based off weapon types which helps dub down the massive roster they have.
That's not to say character play the same. Each has their own signature moves with each weapon and different base stats making lets say one characters having the ability to do the russian mafia combo or whatever with the gloves while a different character may not. However further more, you level these characters up and you can give them different stances with sacrifice a point in 1 stat for another. So now homie who couldn't do the russian mafia, sacrifices 1 point strength to gain 1 point dexterity and boom - now he is fast enough to pull the combo off.

First of all, this game is a lot of fun, but it's also really bad to the point of being frustrating. It feels like it's stuck in 2016. The hurt boxes can be extremely jank, and interactions can get really awkward. Sometimes you're just stuck in neutral praying to just hit something even though you're right next to your opponent. Another thing about this game is that it's extremely easy. There is very little depth and I was able to pick it up right away, which is a bit nice. The issue that arises with this is that people with very little skill can win. Since heavy attacks have huge hurt boxes and a lot of active frames, they are very difficult to punish, which encourages heavy spam. I can normally deal with it, but when someone has good fundies and heavy spams, there's not much that can be done in mid level game play.  This leads me to my next point; ranked is all over the place. I will three stock a gold player then get three stocked by a silver player. Most of the time, the hardest players to beat are the defaults. People with skins typically are pretty bad at the game. Another issue I have with the game is how poorly designed some of the weapons are. A lot of them (sword, katars, rocket lance, greatsword, axe) you literally just mash and beat those who actually labbed out their weapon combos and strings. Other weapons (spear and bow) have only one combo that you constantly fish for, resulting in repetitive game play. 

Over all, I do think this is one of the best platform fighters out there, though the game play is too linear and repetitive. It feels nice to be able to pickup and play a game like this, because some of the strings are really nice to hit, though there's not much else to learn, it's all just refining fundies once you learn all the weapons.

Edit: Ok... this game is sick... I feel like a lot of issues that the game has could easily be fixed with a sequel (Poor graphic design/ poor move design) but the strong suits that the game does have are excellent. You feel really cool doing just about everything. The game play relies on the reading of movement and dodges rather than focusing on whiff punishment which can lead to some awkward neutral, especially when the hurtboxes of the weapons have massive dead zones. Mid level play still feels a bit shabby with how little skill some weapons take along with the many bs ways you can take a stock, but when a match is hard fought, it feels so good win or lose. 

The only reason I'm keeping a negative review is due to Brawlhalla still feeling like a really good game from 2016 and I'm a prick. Still a good game, I wouldn't really recommend it to someone who is trying fighting games for the first time as there are much better platform fighting games out there. *cough cough* smash *cough*

I really like the character designs, and different fighting techniques everyone has. One minute you might be fighting with a big, heavy hammer, and the next you might be fighting with a small, agile sword. It's great. Plus combo moves are really easy to memorise. One complaint though, some characters are very easy to spam with.

The games is quite fun if your looking for a competitive or even fun game to play with friends. It might be 2d but the range of legends/characters along with the vast comboes and maps makes up for it. However, I find the 2d dimension of the game quite nice.

I actually have over 1,000 hours on this game, and as such, I recommend this game to everyone. Don't listen to people that call it a Smash clone. It is extremely unique. I genuinely think this game is good. I love the gameplay, I like the characters and their little bits of lore, the insane combos and strings, etc,,,
But.
The community is the most sweaty, toxic and frankly childishly competitive one I've seen in a while.
54 legends? That's great, too bad you'll only be seeing the same 10 that have had an edge over every other legend for months if not years and the devs seem to have done close to nothing to level the playing field.

The game itself aside, the amount of smurfs and people willingly deranking because it's funny to massacre lower level players for easy gains is frankly quite fascinating and stunting for many, It's the reason the 5 friends I used to play this game with quit.

If you have friends to play with and you're all either depressed or immune to salt, then go ahead and play this game.
If none of your friends play this game and/or you're prone to rage on games, stay as far away from the steaming pile of matchmaking salt that is this game.

Great concept and game, terrible players. Over 80 percent of players spam the same moves. It blows my mind how bad this game has gotten. Like, just buy a certain character and spam a move or two for the whole flipping game. The developers need to fix this problem asap. I'e played this game for about 2 years now, and would probably be the equivalent of a mid platinum player if my internet was good enough. And never have I even seen an attempt to fix the spamming problems. Why are so many players quitting this game? Because of spammers. Spammers are the core of the problem. Remove their ability to spam, or severely weaken it at least, and this game would rise up. Everything else is great, graphics, basic mechanics, controls, customisation, everything. So once the spamming problem is cleared, I'll give this an amazing review. Until then, this game is slowly dying, the fragments inherited by people who ultimately want to make you delete the game.
