Brawlhalla is an entertaining fighter with fun, punchy combat that just about manages to capture that “one more match” feeling. While it isn't quite as tightly designed as the seminal Super Smash Bros., the large roster, wide range of modes, and a reasonable level of depth help it achieve a similar balance of accessibility and challenge - you can play as casually or as competitively as you like. With pay-to-win nowhere to be seen and exceedingly good online play, this is one free-to-play title that's well worth a try.

Overall an ideal game for those who seek fast-paced competitive games (especially 1v1) with a large learning curve, or if you'd like a chill game with friends with its unique set of party-themed game modes. The most appealing aspect of the game is probably landing long combos on opponents and wiping their stock after they just spawned B). Although the in-game tutorial barely teaches you about what to do in a match, youtube is a great source for 'proper' tutorials into the game and provides information to help you develop your gameplay no matter what level you're at.

Gameplay: There are a large scope of movement and attack options ranging in complexity which allows you to play at any skill level. At low level, most players spam heavy attacks due to the convenience of their large hitboxes, but they eventually hit a road block where they actually need to learn how to use movement and attacks to progress towards beating more skilled players. In mid level players develop more on these things as well as learning combos for weapons (there are a lot). There is a training mode to practice these in. At high level, players know how to play neutral, which is the state where both players are on stage and are trying to damage their opponent whilst avoiding damage. A large mix of different movement options to throw your opponent off-guard is vital to thrive against high level opponents. Overall, gameplay can be very fast paced (especially if both players aggro often). Although matches can be boring/frustrating when playing against passive players, there is a feature to help reduce passive play (you can't cling on the walls for very long or you fall off the map). Additionally there is 2v2 as a main game mode where you can set up team combos with your teammate and completely kill off a stock of your opponent... satisfying as hell but very difficult.

Variety/Customisation: Over 50 characters to play with 6 unique heavy attacks each. Each character uses 2 weapons (out of the 13) where each weapon has a large variety of moves and combos. There are a plethora of skins and crossovers with an insane amount of different themes.

Party: Up to 8 people can play in a custom lobby where you are able to play a variety of game modes like soccer, capture the flag, basketball with bombs, tag etc. Very fun to f**k around in.

Yes the game is completely free, there are many characters and add-ons in the game, the developers organize streams where you can get involved and get a lot of things, but even that somehow doesn't fill me enough to enjoy playing this game.

What annoys me the most is the movement in this game, despite the relatively large training, the characters make me different movements or attacks than I would like at the moment, and one such movement can affect the whole match.

From now on, I stop participating in tournaments, ranked games and other challenges that the game offers.

Brawlhalla is an innovative and wonderfully built platform fighter. It uses movement to emphasize creative play, and has a low enough skill floor to get started, and a good enough ranked progression system to keep anyone entertained as they attempt to reach the impossibly high skill ceiling. Reaching a road block as you attempt to learn is natural, but when you break through that block, it is incredibly satisfying.

TLDR; whether you want a competitive platform fighter with a fun and interesting play cycle, or just want a casual Smash clone to play with your friends cross-platform, Brawlhalla is free for everyone and is worth trying out.

I have almost 800 hours on this game already, starting levels are fun tin,silver,gold etc... but in the later levels people really try their hardest to win meaning spammers and people that throw their weapons are not so rare anymore (which I don't blame the developers for!) everything in the game is really expensive so I can see that the developers are pretty money hungry, The graphics are 2D so making a new map is literally drawing a image in ms paint, nothing more nothing less yet still you are playing the same few maps that are avabile. People say the game is balanced and the legends and weapons are equal... yes they are equally garbage. Hitboxes are all over the place, if you are supposed to hit it doesn't hit, if you aren't supposed to hit it hits. bugs with wallgrabs, attacks that don't hit even tho the animation is playing or the hit sound plays but there is no animation making me very confused if in case you play with the sounds too not just by paying attention to animations because I think it's kinda inportant to hear a wallgrab, weapon pickup/throw or hit,  the NONSTOP connectivity issues, this game has made hundreds of thousands (if not milions) of dollars yet they still can't upgrade their servers, servers are laggy and the input lag is just unbearable at this point. (if you even connect) and they are investing 90% of their time and resources into making crossovers (there are more crossovers than champions at this point). BMG is not a small company with very little popularity and no esport anymore. Game is played by tons of people daily and there are very little ammount of things you can do wrong making such a simple game like this but BMG is still a champ at it. In conclusion, the game is fun when you are a newbie, until you start noticing stuff that actually matter and are a big part of the game/gameplay. The recent news about BMG not giving a F*** about the game and community anymore is just gutwrenching, banning pros for their opinions and everyone leaving including most of the biggest names is just sad. That is what the devs deserve tho, make a trash product,treat us like trash-get trash reviews. I think that is fair.

Great game for experience competitiveness

But I have a huge BUT... they removed the ingame/match chat so you no longer can text to your opponent after a match, thinking it because if they people can't text they cant be toxic... Problem is that the toxic chatting and so on was part of the game it was a part of the experience of competitive gameplay by removing the chat feature I now feel like I am playing against no one... there's isn't a human on the other end and it removes from the experience.

Honestly was a great game before and they just made it unsatisfying by removing core mechanics of the competitive experience... f**k investors and being kid-friendly I want the raw experience back.. or at least a toggle button for chat.

TLDR: Fun to play with friends, was satisfying to play competitive but now not as much.

Honestly, this game is pretty fun in general, but the ranked in this game is kind of weird. You will meet four types of players in ranked which is 1, The Average player which just plays like any other player around your rank. 2, The absolute monster Sandstorm mode good player which immediately beats you up into a 3-0. 3, The Sig-Spammer which... do i even have to explain this? They just spam signatures... and last but not least, the afks. The rank system in this game is kindof unfair too cause you will meet people around your rank and then the next game you meet a esports player on the next. Now time to wrap up this review, this game is a really fun game to play if your just chilling with your friends because its just simple. You dont need to do those cool 0 to death combos to actually play the game. Just play this game with friends and chill, do a couple sig spams, laugh around, and if you dont have some friends to play this game with then... unlucky.

ey preety good . High ass skill celling . Lots of universal stuff so only 1-2 characters are bad. Great charcter variety . Weapons feel different . 
BUT
preety steep learning curve imo . Movement in this game is the trick for any win and its hard to learn such a system that rewards long term and not short term. Not a bad thing.  
Its more about adaptation than long combos and reaction timing cuz many , many interactions happen in any said game.
The best thing by far is that i always think when i lose , damn i didnt utilize all my kit correctly , i am gold mind you, which is a preety good thing the game has taught me . I understand why i lost always upon second inspection
Transitioning from playing a character you like to another is also easy because some combos are universal and characters can share light attack kits due to having the same weapon
Stats are a bit unbalanced , with dex being by far the worst , but its not as bad as you might think for 90% of the cast
Last but not least FREQUENT UPDATES. If something is rly broken it gets patched asap

Good things:
- It's very fun, especially with friends.
- You can be a casual player, a try hard, or a pro player.
- Arguably one of the easiest fighting games to learn (very hard to master tho)
- Very low waiting time and quick game-play (I love quick game-play).
Bad things:
- I couldn't come up with many bad things about the game other than the fact that the concept isn't new and has been used before (that isn't necessarily bad but yk can't just be positive).

Would I recommend this to the average player? Absolutely 110%
Would I recommend this to a try hard? Absolutely 100%
Would I recommend this to an old person? Not really 

Overall: 9.2/10

The honest truth for me at least about this game is its the one you randomly see scrolling through youtube seeing pros do god like combos like its easy so you download it and realize they've worked so hard to get where they are. You decide to give up and go back to whatever you were playing before forgetting all about it. Years go by until you see it again and you realized as bad as you were at it, it was pretty fun. You re-download it and slowly play more and more day by day, making new friends along the way slowly improving and climbing the ranks, more years go by and you have more friends then you know what to do with you realize you love the game, not because its intense not because its easy but because you enjoy throwing on some music and hopping into a call or playing alone and just having fun.

Brawlhalla is an epic platform fighter for up to 8 players online or local. Try casual free-for-alls, ranked matches, or invite friends to a private room. And it's free! Play cross-platform with millions of players on PlayStation, Xbox, Nintendo Switch, iOS, Android & Steam! Frequent updates. Over fifty Legends.

ABOUT THIS GAME

Brawlhalla: History's greatest warriors brawl to prove who's the best in an epic test of strength and skill. These slugfests are salted with powerful weapons and gadgets. Every weapon you pick up changes your style of play

Brawlhalla is a free 2D platform fighting game that supports up to 8 local or online players with full cross-play for PC, PS5, PS4, Xbox Series X|S, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, iOS and Android!

Features:

Online Ranked 1v1 - Climb the ranked ladder from Tin up to Platinum and beyond! Matches you against players near your skill level.

Online Ranked 2v2 - Climb the ranked ladder with a friend! Matches you and a partner against teams near you skill level. Your friend can be online or right next to you.

4 Player Online Free for All - Casual matches where four fighters enter, but only one can win.

Cross-play Custom Rooms - Invite up to 8 friends on PC, PS5, PS4, Xbox Series X|S, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, iOS, Android, or Locally to a huge variety of custom matches: 4v4s, 1v3, 2v2, FFA, and much more.

Many Game Modes - Mix things up with Brawlball, Bombsketball, Capture the Flag, Kung-Foot, and many more fun party game modes.

The Training Room - Practice combos and setups inside the Training Room! Look at detailed frame data, hitboxes, hurtboxes, and sharpen your skills.

Plus: Best-in-class spectating, match recording and replay. Dozens of maps. Single player tournament mode. An online brawl-of-the-week. Experimental mode. Millions of players for fast matchmaking. Regional servers for low-latency online play. Frequent updates. Tons of esports events and tournaments. Excellent support for keyboard and controllers. Career history and cool progress rewards. Ranked seasons. Friendly devs. Fun, fair free-to-play. And much more.

How we do Free to Play

Brawlhalla will always be 100% free to play with no pay-to-win advantages and no in-game purchases to keep you from the action. Everything you can buy with real money is cosmetic (such as character skins, podiums, and KO effects) and none of them effect gameplay.

The Legend Rotation of nine free to play characters changes every week, and you can earn gold to unlock more Legends by playing any online game mode.

You can also check out our “All Legends Pack” that immediately unlocks every character we’ve ever made, and ever will make. Forever. Everything in the “Legends” tab in the in-game store would be yours to have. Note that this doesn’t unlock Crossovers.

Here's what you can expect from Brawlhalla

Weekly patches and updates.
Online, custom, ranked, and local play modes.
Over 50 Legends (and counting) to chose from and a free 9 character weekly rotation, unlockable with gold earned through playing the game.
Loads of stages to fight on.
Unique signature moves, weapon combinations and stats for each character.
Ranked seasons every three months with seasonal rewards for playing ranked.
A constant stream of new features, balance tweaks and Legends to make the game better and better.
Excited Devs active everywhere eagerly listening to what you think!
Our eternal thanks (you're our favorite).

We’re always listening to community feedback and value what players are telling us. Throughout Early Access the Brawlhalla community helped steer the direction of development multiple times to make Brawlhalla the best it can be. That will remain the same as we continue to improve, expand, and adjust Brawlhalla based on community feedback post-launch.

Brawlhalla. 

Visually it looks like a mobile game (it is), the production quality is very very low. The design of everything around you is essentially just a still image. The menu looks and feels very clunky, making it annoying to navigate. The in-game purchase monetization is HEAVY, but also extremely inconsistent. Characters have different stats that make them better in different ways, and you can buy every single character (50+) for about 15$, or you could buy them all one at a time for 6$ each, or you could play for countless hours to grind each of them out. I would say please give me an explanation but it’s blatantly clear that it is pay to win. Beyond that every single cosmetic costs real world money and is overpriced largely. The pricing of everything in the game does not change by region, so depending on where you live you could be paying much less or much much more for everything. Oh and I almost forgot, there’s a battle pass too. Everything I just said is what is wrong with current day video games, and it is all in Brawlhalla. But now I’ll talk about the actual gameplay.

The mechanics are surprisingly deep and very fun. It’s addicting to land huge combos on people and watch them fly out view and light speed. With the amount of characters that there are, you can master and learn MANY different techniques, so the game has a wide variety in characters and skill. The controls are also great! Normally I would never even dare to play a fighting game on a mouse and keyboard but it is genuinely very good in this game. Everything is bindable and changeable. Very accessible to people who want to play their own way. HOWEVER, the game can be hard to play sometimes because of its own faults. The servers are complete dick ass, very often lagging and ruining competitive matches (especially in third world countries). The hitboxes are inconsistent and make less sense the more you play. More often than not I'm having a great time in matches but the fact that it can go this badly during a ranked game is not good at all.

SO, with all that information taken in and absorbed, I can heartfully say fuck this game. There are so many different fighting games you could be spending your time on that are 100% absolutely better than Brawlhalla. This game is competent in it’s controls and mechanics but other than that, Brawlhalla is a scummy cash grab of a video game.

as a somewhat experienced player i can say this game is not worth playing and is way dying at a slow pace. The game feels very polished and has good cosmetics. However, this game is really hard to approach for new players and also has a very toxic community. The gameplay is generally fun but when you make it past a certain point you notice a passive meta. This game has a very obvious passive meta where you often just have a match of 2 people waiting for the other person to make a move. The passive meta is very important though as you cannot win a high elo match without passive. This causes 3 minute games to take double the time. Passive meta subjectively (for most people) isn't fun because you can't actually go for anything.

I play Super Smash on console when the friends come over, but when were all at home on our PC's Brawlhalla is our fighting game. We will play for hours, changing characters, trying different weapons, different fighting modes and maps. Its a blast. I'm even having fun in ranked play. You can easily have hours of fun if your playing for free, but eventually if you decide you like the game, its totally worth it to get the "All Legends Pack". It gives you all past, current, and future legends for $14.99 USD (On sale right now).  There are other sites that sell it cheaper *waggles eyebrows*, but I payed through the game to make sure the creators get paid for the amazing job they have done and continue to do. Because I forgot to mention that despite the game being released in 2015, the creators are STILL putting out new champions, weapons, maps, amazing skins, you name it! Also, nothing you can buy in the store effects stats, keeping it out of the pay to win category. It's pretty much everything my group has been looking for in a fighting game.

If you want a review from a non fighter game player then here you go.
Brawlhalla is a game I enjoyed for about 2ish years from 2017. I met a lot of my friends through the after game chat and its actually my most played game (which I'm oddly proud of).But as of 2020 I've noticed a lot has changed within the player mental. It's very spammy and taunty. From what I gather is there's no hidden mmr within the normal games because I'm always matched with spammers and even though I'm bad I can still beat them with real combos instead of just pressing Queen Nai sigs. I'm not queued with gamers that are neutral at the game. After they sig they taunt. Imagine being new and sding and they do the read u taunt.I do believe it's a fun game for friends. I play ranked 2v2 with friends when I do play. The fact one of us could 1v2 is soo funny to see when we're yelling in call saying " DON'T THROW".The controls are very easy, all the characters have the same unarmed moves,characters have fun skins (crossovers) ,podiums look pretty and the game modes from time to time are interesting to say the least. 
I've spent so many hours in this game I can't possibly say it's bad but it's not better then other fighting games.
the first 100 hours when you didn't know how to play properly was pretty fun. after that it get boring . i wouldn't recommend this game unless to have a group of friends to play with.

The game used to run much smoother previously now it takes your character 1 hour to attack after clicking. (offline works perfectly fine so its definately not my computer)

Never before have I experienced such a god-awful catastrophe; let me explain.

About one and a half years ago, I was laying peacefully asleep in the comfort of my home, until the clock struck twelve. From under my door arose The Wicked Spirit of Foda (the undead phantasm of a Brawlhalla developer), as it strangled me and possessed my body.

Sadly, the spirit had not entirely taken over my conscious, ergo I was still involuntarily experiencing the actions of Foda. For over one thousand hours, I struggled to flee the spirit from my body, but it was to no avail. 

Fast-forward to present day, when the evil demon had dropped out of plat for the eighth time in one season  because of a dog water, piss-gurgling, 8 year old, brainlet, blunderbuss sig-spammer using teros as an absolute wheelchair for all three stocks. The spirit was so enraged at the stupendously goofy shabbaroon while playing this game, that it committed suicide on the spot, freeing me from its wrath.

Countless hours I spent under the influence of the wicked spirit, awaiting the day I was free from playing and watching this utter chuckle head of a video game. I shall never get those one and a half years of pain back, so to show my displeasure, I leave this warning sign to any other - even those who have the thought of playing this repulsive game cross their mind.

Brawlhalla is an epic platform fighter for up to 8 players online or local. Try casual free-for-alls, ranked matches, or invite friends to a private room. And it's free! Play cross-platform with millions of players on PlayStation, Xbox, Nintendo Switch, iOS, Android & Steam! Frequent updates. Over fifty Legends.

ABOUT THIS GAME

Brawlhalla: History's greatest warriors brawl to prove who's the best in an epic test of strength and skill. These slugfests are salted with powerful weapons and gadgets. Every weapon you pick up changes your style of play

Brawlhalla is a free 2D platform fighting game that supports up to 8 local or online players with full cross-play for PC, PS5, PS4, Xbox Series X|S, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, iOS and Android!

Features:

Online Ranked 1v1 - Climb the ranked ladder from Tin up to Platinum and beyond! Matches you against players near your skill level.

Online Ranked 2v2 - Climb the ranked ladder with a friend! Matches you and a partner against teams near you skill level. Your friend can be online or right next to you.

4 Player Online Free for All - Casual matches where four fighters enter, but only one can win.

Cross-play Custom Rooms - Invite up to 8 friends on PC, PS5, PS4, Xbox Series X|S, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, iOS, Android, or Locally to a huge variety of custom matches: 4v4s, 1v3, 2v2, FFA, and much more.

Many Game Modes - Mix things up with Brawlball, Bombsketball, Capture the Flag, Kung-Foot, and many more fun party game modes.

The Training Room - Practice combos and setups inside the Training Room! Look at detailed frame data, hitboxes, hurtboxes, and sharpen your skills.

Plus: Best-in-class spectating, match recording and replay. Dozens of maps. Single player tournament mode. An online brawl-of-the-week. Experimental mode. Millions of players for fast matchmaking. Regional servers for low-latency online play. Frequent updates. Tons of esports events and tournaments. Excellent support for keyboard and controllers. Career history and cool progress rewards. Ranked seasons. Friendly devs. Fun, fair free-to-play. And much more.

How we do Free to Play

Brawlhalla will always be 100% free to play with no pay-to-win advantages and no in-game purchases to keep you from the action. Everything you can buy with real money is cosmetic (such as character skins, podiums, and KO effects) and none of them effect gameplay.

The Legend Rotation of nine free to play characters changes every week, and you can earn gold to unlock more Legends by playing any online game mode.

You can also check out our “All Legends Pack” that immediately unlocks every character we’ve ever made, and ever will make. Forever. Everything in the “Legends” tab in the in-game store would be yours to have. Note that this doesn’t unlock Crossovers.

Here's what you can expect from Brawlhalla

Weekly patches and updates.
Online, custom, ranked, and local play modes.
Over 50 Legends (and counting) to chose from and a free 9 character weekly rotation, unlockable with gold earned through playing the game.
Loads of stages to fight on.
Unique signature moves, weapon combinations and stats for each character.
Ranked seasons every three months with seasonal rewards for playing ranked.
A constant stream of new features, balance tweaks and Legends to make the game better and better.
Excited Devs active everywhere eagerly listening to what you think!
Our eternal thanks (you're our favorite).

We’re always listening to community feedback and value what players are telling us. Throughout Early Access the Brawlhalla community helped steer the direction of development multiple times to make Brawlhalla the best it can be. That will remain the same as we continue to improve, expand, and adjust Brawlhalla based on community feedback post-launch.

Some background on the game.

The game is a fighting platformer game where the goal is to flip the enemies off the map. The game is available on all platforms, and can be played by up to 4 players

At the same time. Familiar game is free, and can run on any computer. The game is reminiscent of Nintendo's super smash bros game.
The gameplay

The gameplay of the game will never bore you. At every moment in the game you will do something. The gameplay is fast and each game takes about 5 minutes.

The game has several game modes:
Free for all:

The game has 4 players. The length of the game is 4 minutes and the goal is to be the player with the highest number of points.

If you kill a person, you will get 2 points and for a person you kill, you will get one point.

If you just fall, you will lose 3 points.

StrikeOut 1v1:
One-on-one battle, in which each player has 3 lives. At the beginning of the game you will choose 3 characters, with whom you will play during the game. Every time you die,

You will get the next character you choose in order until someone dies completely.

2v2s:
In the game there are 2 game modes where 2 players will play against 2 players, one competitive and one not. Each player has 3 lives and the difference between the game modes is

That in competition it is possible to hurt team members and usually not.

1v1 & experimental:
Here too, Yahweh 2 players with 3 lives will have to fight until one dies completely. In Experimental there are things that are examined like maps and moves,

Which will probably add to the game. In a standard one-on-one there are no such things (1 on 1 competitive).

 

The characters + the weapons

There are currently 45 characters in the game, and more are always being added. Each week Yahweh has 8 free characters that you can play this week, and always

You can buy characters with the money you get in the game. If you buy a character that is free, after the week it is free it will always stay with you.
The exclamation mark indicates whether the character is free.

Each character has different stats and 2 different weapons.
Game keys:

The game has several ways to play the game: the WASD and J K L keys

Arrow keys and X C V

WASD SHIFT keys and all mouse keys.

(These are the recommended settings, but you can still play with the arrows and the mouse for example, but these are the recommended settings.

I recommend for those who have a controller to play with a controller, because I have tried all the options and the most convenient controller for me.
I will explain how to play with the WASD and mouse keys.

To move we will use WASD

If we press Shift and adjust with D / A we will do a Dash (if we slide) and if we press Shift in the air / towards the floor or the sky will slip away, which is useful to return to the map

If we fall or try to dodge someone's attack.

If we press the left button on the mouse we will hit a quick hit

A middle click will throw away a weapon or object you are holding

If we right-click on the mouse we will hit a special hit. Each character has a set of different special attacks.

Each blow has several types, and it depends on its direction. For example: if you press S + left button the hit will be different from D + left button.
It was less of a criticism but it was an explanation.

Unironically the best fighter game I've ever played. Well put together, though it still has the flaws that other games of this type have such as input delay and server lag, but you can't really do much about that. Interesting competitive scene, tons of characters with unique play-styles, and all of it is accessible for free. The only in-game purchases are for useless cosmetics, as well as an instant unlock for every legend if you're that lazy.

I highly recommend this game if you're looking for an alternative to smash or the like, or even just to have a fun and chill game to screw around with friends in.

When I started playing this game over two years ago on the xbox, I was blown away by the completely original way of fighting. The game uses a set of weapons, that each character will have two of, that have their own fighting style connected to it. At first, I mained cannon characters, as it seemed easier to control them with a controller. But later on, I started using gauntlet character. The base style of fighting connected to the gauntlets connected to my play style very well because most of the attacks made it so that I could maneuver around the stages with ease. I always say that to be the best, move around in the most unreadable fashion while also reading each move the opponent has to basically predict every action they take. Sounds like a lot but that's truly how you win. The fighting system along with the progression system made me fall in love with this game. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a free to play game or for even a game in general.

Brawlhalla is an alright 2D character platformer. I have to give the game credit it's art style gives it an incredible sense of direction and a solid platform to build off of. The combat is solid and fun, even though the weapons are classified in similar categories each character makes the weapons feel like their own. This game is free so why not take the gamble, add this game to your library I urge you to try it. I especially can't recommend it enough if you play with your friends. All in all it is an average game but through solid mechanics it can make it one of the most fun experience you can have.

the servers are absolutely terrible for a game that requires split second inputs. they fluctuate from bad, horrible, reasonable, and every once in a blue moon, fast. but the fast times are fleeting and rare and it makes you want to pull your hair out. nomatter what you do you will never be able to fix the issue. whether you buy a faster computer, internet, peripherals. and for some reason, their ranked set up causes lag in order to "balance", which just ends up gimping both parties. the only way this game is fairly competitive is if you happen to be lucky and live in a place where the connection is fluid. but ive lived in 4 different places and i havent found it. if i were you i would avoid this game like the plague unless you want to spend alot of money to fix an unfixable problem in order to chase an opportunity to actually be rewarded for your talent. im plat 5 because i hit a streak of good internet ONE DAY. but mostly i get pushed back down to low plat, and even sometimes high gold. save yourself the headache. the game would be brilliant if it actually did what it was supposed to.

All over the game and graphics are alright but could be better. Simple things and the game is fun if you are in couch party in but to be honest you don't have to spend extreme time on it to get good, all you need are some arms and hands then you'd be on your way. The store is nothing extreme but can be annoying if you have things that you want in the shop but they normally add battle passes with a relation to the story. (You don't have to know the story literally just look up what to do for most of the challenges or you can look inside of the game for the challenges.) Things from the shop don't make you better just for cosmetics. Legends are put behind coins and they get given for free after every game based on your performance in the game. There are competitive modes that you can play if you want to climb the ranked ladder but for a casual player that doesn't matter. The game is very easy to just jump in and leave after a couple of games and is fun to just play in general each legend has different style and signatures while playing the game. All it is is that you have to push another player off the screen. Brawlhalla has different shows and games that they partner with like ninja turtles and street fighter being the most recent ones. Content inside of the game is okay, Brawl of the week is a fun lot of games every week changing weekly with some coming back. anyway all you need to know about the game is that its fun to play with friends and you don't need to spend a whole lot of time to get good while also having a competitive scene for it as well.

Fun PC fighting game.  Very similar to Nintendo's Super Smash Bros. franchise.  A ton of unique characters called Legends to play as.

Gameplay-wise, matches are short and sweet, pretty easy to get into, but still has some depth. Coupled with dozen of weapons with their own playstyle and legends having a pair of them with their own signature attacks make for a great game for both casual and competitive players.

Naturally, as a free game, this game has its own premium currency. Though you can play the game without paying a dime and technically you're never at a disadvantage,
1. Unlocking a legend will be a long grind. For context:
-Most legends cost 5600 coins, with the exception of older and newest ones (2800 and 7400 respectively)
-You receive around ~20 coins per match with 100 coin mission everyday, with a small incremental 5 day login bonus. (50 coins to 250 coins)

If you were to play 10 matches everyday, finish daily mission and not miss day in between, it'd take you around 2 weeks for ONE legend. Of course you can skip the hassle and bust out the credit card.

2. Some cosmetics are over the top and downright misleading. Fireballs that look nothing like what it is supposed to look like (guns), and signature effects that does not effectively portray hitboxes, crossover skins that keep you guessing as to which legend it is (mirror of) etc.

For couch play, there is no catch up or fun/quirky mechanic. You'll basically end up spamming buttons hoping you knock the other guy before they do. You're better off with different game for more fun couch play.

Would I recommend it? It's free, why not?
This is a fun free little Smash type fighting game with in-depth mechanics and fun fights

The game is pretty fun for a party fighter, similar to smash bros but with alot less variation between characters which can come off as a bit underwhelming if switching to this. The crossplay is very good for this game as there is no unfair advantages between console and pc other than maybe frames. The gameplay is good too. My main gripe is with the matchmaking, especially in ranked. The game will match you with players up to 100 elo higher than you, which can end some exciting win streaks out of sheer luck. It can also deter new players very easily as nothing stops them from getting destroyed by higher skill players in say, free for all. There is also minor changes that need to be addressed like true sig combos. This game also has a tendency to kill your soul, it has depressed me beyond belief and i am unable to sleep at night because of true combo nightmares. Please pray for me that i reach plat rank :) (am at 1628 rn)

Recipe for chicken soup:
1 (3 pound) whole chicken

4 carrots, halved

4 stalks celery, halved

1 large onion, halved

water to cover

salt and pepper to taste

1 teaspoon chicken bouillon granules (Optional)
Put the chicken, carrots, celery and onion in a large soup pot and cover with cold water. Heat and simmer, uncovered, until the chicken meat falls off of the bones (skim off foam every so often).

Step 2
Take everything out of the pot. Strain the broth. Pick the meat off of the bones and chop the carrots, celery and onion. Season the broth with salt, pepper and chicken bouillon to taste, if desired. Return the chicken, carrots, celery and onion to the pot, stir together, and serve.

Final Fantasy was the game of my childhood. So, I am used to a battle system where heavier weapons are much noticeably slower and deliver more damage per hit than lighter weapons. In fact, often times heavier weapons could not even conduct combos like lighter weapons could. In that sense, Brawlhalla does not fit that. You can have a very high speed character like Artemis using a heavy weapon like lance doing easy multi-hit combos. Usually, signature attacks have to be charged in games since they deliver so much more damage than lighter attacks, but Brawlhalla has no charging system, so signatures can be spammed willy-nilly. I would say that if you simply are not allowed to buy games with real money or can not afford to buy games, Brawlhalla is a good game. It is fun to play with friends. However, if you are willing to buy games on Steam, I do not think Brawlhalla is very good at all. There are plenty of other fighting games that deliver better animation, better hitboxes, better fighting strategies than Brawlhalla. In fact, modded Minecraft BedWars is better than Brawlhalla in my opinion. Regarding the community of Brawlhalla, I would say it is quite toxic. Even though the developers took away post-game chat, players still invite other players to their rooms and use very foul language. I do not think I have been called the n-word so many times in my life than in Brawlhalla. If you are parent reading this, then I recommend you take the extra effort to buy your kid a good game with a good community. This game just is not it.

It was pretty fun. While it lasted, that is. You have to try and make the most out of your gameplay, or it will soon get boring, or just plain not fun. I've got a lot to say about the game, but most of that is due to my own errors, so I'll leave that out.

Game can have frame drops even on good PCs, and the server connection is *decent* but not consistent. You can be on your way to three-stocking someone and then end up running off of the stage due to the server connection. Not to mention, if you're on Wi-Fi (even fast networks), the connection to the servers can end of varying a ton.

It's fun with friends, provided you're around the same skill level, because beating the same person(s) over and over again, or being beat by the same person(s) over and over again gets boring quite fast. Well, unless you're a sadist or masochist. Or both.

Brawlhalla is definitely one of the more interesting platforming game. When I first saw this game, I immediately thought that it would be somekind of a smash clone. Oh how wrong I was when I first thought of that. Brawlhalla got me very hooked and the game is incredibly fun. On a casual level, the game is definitely really fluid as the game itself is very simple and there are countless of different game modes and characters. But not everyone plays fighting games only for enjoyment. Some people take it to the next level and want to compete to be the very best players. Brawlhalla got you covered with that also. The game can be very competitive and learning this game can be very enjoyable. Not only that, Brawlhalla even supports official tournaments that you can compete for huge cash. The esport scene is definitely one of the spicier things about the game as it really gives huge inspiration for many players. However, even with a lot of ups Brawlhalla has a lot of flaws that I can't miss out on. The game can get stale if I am being honest. There are not that many content in the game and most of the time what you do is just polishing your skills. Lore in this game is also incredibly awful since there is no story mode and characters' lore are just mentioned in a 5 paragraph long essay description. Once you get through the highest rank, you will hit that skill ceiling and improving skill becomes much more limited. Due to Brawlhalla's simple nature, training to become the very best can be stale, even when you can do some crazy stuff on high level. To put it simply, the game is not as enjoyable to learn once you get up there. For me, I have been highly ranked (2149), and despite some flaws I have mentioned, this game has always managed to addict me since it is so simple and accessible to everyone coupled with great online and enjoyable learning experience. Great game for casuals and high level play, but the lack of content can make it stale once you reach the skill ceiling. 8.5/10

I have been playing Brawlhalla for over 800 hours so far (PS4+PC) and I can definitely say that it is a great game. First the balance, since every character is very similar with shared weapons, hurtbox, mechanics, etc. all of the characters feel viable. The only differences between them being their weapon combinations, stats, and signatures. Second and third, the netcode and accessibility. It uses rollback netcode, so the online matches feel very smooth with little if none input lag. This game can be played FREE on PC, PS4, Xbox, Switch, iPhone, and Android with cross play available between all of the platforms. My only gripe is that there is not yet cross save, so you must restart your account in order to play on another device. All in all, try the game out and see if you like it. With its free price tag and minimal space consumption, there is not much to lose.

Strawberry Cheesecake French Toast

Ingredients:

4 Slices Bread
4 Eggs
1 Tablespoon Vanilla
1 Cup Milk
1 Tablespoon Cinnamon
4 oz. Warm Cream Cheese
2 Tablespoons Vanilla Extract
2 Tablespoons Lemon Juice
¾ Cup Heavy Cream
1 ½ Cups Strawberry, Diced, Divided
⅓ Cup Sugar
Confectioners Sugar
Maple Syrup

Preparation:

1.Whisk eggs, cinnamon, vanilla and milk together in medium-large bowl to create egg wash.

2. In medium bowl mix cream cheese, vanilla, sugar, lemon juice and heavy cream (optional).

3. Take 2 slices of bread and spread mixture on both.

4. Press sliced strawberries on both slices & press together.

5. Dunk in egg wash.

6. Melt butter in a skillet on medium-low heat and cook bread for 2-3 minutes or until crumbs are crispy and bread is more solid.

7. Stack and garnish with strawberries and confectioners sugar. Add maple syrup to preference.

The amount of time I've spent in this game would be surprising considering the score I'm giving it, but I cannot seriously recommend Brawlhalla when there are so many better ways to use your time. There's NO community in any online game I've faced (not even other F2P games such as LoL) that is as toxic as this one is. If you don't live close to one of the servers for this game your connection is jsut utter garbage. You're always gona have some sort of input lag. If you've ever played any fighting game you'll realize this game is very unbalanced and devs just cycle through metas to hype the tournaments up basically as they know exactly what they're doing and it's not balance. There's no penalty for doing or not doing stuff here (NO Rock Paper Scissors type of design you find in literally EVERY OTHER FIGHTING GAME). The whole economy behind this game revolves around being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, taunts are the best selling in-app purchase by a mile. If you don't live in the US (or one of the 1st world countries) then good luck trying to buy anything as the premium in-game currency price isn't region adjusted. The more you play and the farther you get (up to Diamond) the more passive and boring the game becomes. There's footsies, there's defensive oriented characters in other fighting games but this is ridiculous... some matches will be stalemates where your opponent will literally just run away. As a matter of a fact, running away is objectively more effective than anythign else which is an incentive to play passively. Why? Because you have more options to run away, dodge, defend, throw your weapon, etc than you have to approach. Why would I recommend a game whose population is mostly kids yet it has the most toxic players ever? Everyone is tired ofthe toxicity, of the passiveness and the overall same-ness of the game. You don't have to believe me if you don't want to, few people really talk about this but it is the truth. You can check "toxicity Brawlhalla" on Youtube.


The game promotes a competitive scene, yet it lacks any balance to it. The fact they don't do anything about it yet they pour a new skin or toxic taunt every other month tells you what the developers' priorities are (its a business after all). Toxicity is a moneymaker. Even Brawlhalla's top players complain about the things mentioned and even more, yet in years those complaints have not been adressed at all. Boomie (#1-2 player depending on the year) has complained about a lot of stuff throughout the years, Sandstorm (undeniably #1) focuses on playing Smash competitively yet he absolutely DESTROYS this scene, eggsoup (ex-top 8 regular) constantly points out the problems with the community and the meta, dopameme (one of the guys who made the best exhibition combo videos) has complained and left the competitive scene due to several instances of lacking balance. These are people that have thousands of hours poured in the game and they all agree with this.

Most Brawlhalla players will defend the game till the end as a fighting game but have never ever played other fighting games in their life. Being toxic and sending death threats and generally inappropiate slurs is the name of the meta.

The game is addicting, not gonna lie, but I do not recommend it when you have to face an absurd amount of toxicity if you're a casual and an insanely passive and unbalanced meta if you're playing competitively.

A fun platform fighter that works quite differently than other platform fighters. All characters share most of the elements of their moveset - this can make the characters feel a little same-y, but it also means that there can be many more characters, and it also makes it far easier to learn new ones. This also means that characters don't vary wildly in power, because they only have a few moves and stats to set them apart from the rest, and this means that most characters are balanced fairly well.

This also means that the game isn't pay to win. A free to play player doesn't have any significant disadvantage compared to a player who has bought all the characters, because the difference between the strongest and weakest characters is small. I was initially wary of this game's free to play nature, but it's actually handled pretty well - buying all the characters is quite cheap, and doing so doesn't really remove the point of the game, which tends to be a problem in games with similar models. The skins are overpriced, in my opinion; the cheapest, dullest ones are around six dollars worth of currency, and the Epic Crossovers featuring custom effects are more than twelve a piece. But, as they're entirely cosmetic, this isn't a huge point against the game.

Overall? I recommend giving this game a go. I went into it thinking it was just poor man's Smash Bros, but it's genuinely a good time. The characters, while not quite as unique as in other games of the genre, are still fun, and well-balanced besides. The free to play aspects aren't crippling to non-paying players, and they don't take away the fun for paying players. The game regularly receives new content, and the developers seem to listen to the community well.

Oh, and the ability to create a platform in the air and make a grounded attack from it as every single character opens up a crazy amount of fun, satisfying options.

The majority of Japan's junior high and high schools require students to wear uniforms. The Japanese school uniform is not only a symbol of youth but also plays an important role in the country's culture, as they are felt to help instill a sense of discipline and community among youth. There are many types of uniforms that range from standard to unique ones varying in the ensembles used.

The gakuran and sailor-style dress have always been a part of Japan's "growing modern" culture due to its formal appearance and its existence as a concept. Old-fashioned textbooks state that the uniforms were based on the Imperial Japanese Army uniform rather than the European uniforms. The sides of the uniform are similar to existing styles of Japanese dressmaking and the collar had straight lines. Many home economics classes in Japan up until the 1950s gave sewing sailor outfits as assignments. Girls sewed sailor outfits for younger children in their communities. In the 1980s, sukeban gangs began modifying uniforms by making skirts longer and shortening the tops, and so schools began switching to blazer or sweater vest style uniforms to try to combat the effect. As of 2012, 50% of Japanese junior high schools and 20% of senior high schools use sailor suit uniforms. The Asahi Shimbun stated in 2012 that, "The sailor suit is changing from adorable and cute, a look that 'appeals to the boys,' to a uniform that 'girls like to wear for themselves.'" As of that year, contemporary sailor suits have front closures with zippers or snaps and more constructed bodices. The Asahi Shimbun stated that "the form is snug to enhance the figure—the small collar helps the head look smaller, for better balance."

The Japanese junior and senior-high-school uniform traditionally consists of a military-styled uniform for boys and a sailor outfit for girls. These uniforms are based on Meiji-period formal military dress, themselves modeled on European-style naval uniforms. The sailor outfits replace the undivided hakama (known as andon bakama (行灯袴)) designed by Utako Shimoda between 1920 and 1930. While this style of uniform is still in use, many schools have moved to more Western-pattern Catholic school uniform styles. These uniforms consist of a white shirt, tie, blazer with school crest, and tailored trousers (often not of the same color as the blazer) for boys and a white blouse, tie, blazer with school crest, and tartan culottes or skirt for girls.

Regardless of what type of uniform any particular school assigns its students, all schools have a summer version of the uniform (usually consisting of just a white dress shirt and the uniform slacks for boys and a reduced-weight traditional uniform or blouse and tartan skirt with tie for girls) and a sports-activity uniform (a polyester track suit for year-round use and a T-shirt and short pants for summer activities). Depending on the discipline level of any particular school, students may often wear different seasonal and activity uniforms within the same classroom during the day. Individual students may attempt to subvert the system of uniforms by wearing their uniforms incorrectly or by adding prohibited elements such as large loose socks or badges. Girls may shorten their skirts, permanently or by wrapping up the top to decrease length; boys may wear trousers about the hips, omit ties, or keep their shirts unbuttoned.

Since some schools do not have sex-segregated changing- or locker-rooms, students may change for sporting activities in their classrooms. As a result, such students may wear their sports uniforms under their classroom uniforms. Certain schools also regulate student hairstyles, footwear, and book bags; but these particular rules are usually adhered to only on special occasions, such as trimester opening and closing ceremonies and school photo days.

It is normal for uniforms to be worn outside of school areas, but this is going out of fashion and many students wear casual dress outside of school. While not many public elementary schools in Japan require uniforms, many private schools and public schools run by the central government still do so.

The gakuran (学ラン) and the tsume-eri (詰襟) are the uniforms for many middle-school and high-school boys in Japan. The color is normally black, but some schools use navy blue.

The top has a standing collar buttoning down from top-to-bottom. Buttons are usually decorated with the school emblem to show respect to the school. Pants are straight leg and a black or dark-colored belt is worn with them. Boys usually wear penny loafers or sneakers with this uniform. Some schools may require the students to wear collar-pins representing the school and/or class rank.

Traditionally, the gakuran is also worn along with a matching (usually black) student cap, although this custom is less common in modern times.

The gakuran is derived from the Prussian Waffenrock. The term is a combination of gaku (学) meaning "study" or "student", and ran (らん/蘭) meaning the Netherlands or, historically in Japan, the West in general; thus, gakuran translates as "Western style clothes for student (uniform)".

The original model of the present day gakuran was first established in 1886 for the students of Tokyo University. During the Japanese occupation, such clothing was also brought to school in South Korea and pre-1949 China. Nowadays, the gakuran is still worn by some South Korean students.

While the gakuran is associated solely as the boys' uniform of most junior high schools and some high schools nowadays, blazers began to be adopted in most high schools.

Most importantly, the sailor fuku (セーラー服, sērā fuku) (lit. 'sailor outfit') is a common style of uniform worn by female middle school students, traditionally by high school students, and occasionally, elementary school students. It was introduced as a school uniform in 1920 in Heian Jogakuin (平安女学院) and 1921 by the principal of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Jo Gakuin University (福岡女学院), Elizabeth Lee. It was modeled after the uniform used by the British Royal Navy at the time, which Lee had experienced as an exchange student in the United Kingdom.

Much like the male uniform, the gakuran, the sailor outfits bears a similarity to various military styled naval uniforms. The uniform generally consists of a blouse attached with a sailor-style collar and a pleated skirt. There are seasonal variations for summer and winter; sleeve length and fabric are adjusted accordingly. A ribbon is tied in the front and laced through a loop attached to the blouse. Several variations on the ribbon include neckties, bolo ties, neckerchiefs, and bows. Common colors include navy blue, white, gray, light green, and black.

Shoes, socks, and other accessories are sometimes included as part of the uniform. These socks are typically navy or white. The shoes are typically brown or black penny loafers. Although not part of the prescribed uniform, alternate forms of legwear (such as loose socks, knee-length stockings, or similar) are also commonly matched by more fashionable girls with their sailor outfits

This is a very fun and casual little game to play alone or with your friends whenever you feel like playing Smash Bros but can't play it.

The gameplay is very simples to learn with very few and easy to learn controls, such as weak and strong punches and defend/dash. The game gets more exciting as people learn to master those few moves and make amazing plays.

The game has no story, you just drop in a match and play. You can play with friends vs AI, AI only or with other people online, which is very nice to always have that kind of different options to play the game.

The game runs in any computer since it's very light and it's very casual, so you don't have to worry about if the game runs well or if you're gonna lose, so if you haven't played already i recommend trying.

I'd say it's a pretty good game to kill time with if that's what you're looking for, but i would not recommend it for anyone with a strong lack of patience and/or natural skill. Maybe it's the leveling system, maybe it's me, but the game is overrun with sweats. I would've recommended it a few years ago when I played casually for the Switch and the player match-ups felt fair, but I feel like all the players like that were scared off or become op asf. Not trying to sound like a hypocrite with this review since I'm a tryhard at this game now too, but I just wouldn't recommend it to anyone that rages easily or people that aren't willing to take the game seriously.

Brawlhalla is a very enjoyable game to me. Though it is similar to smash bros. by the platforming fighter aspect it is also different in many ways. Brawlhalla has a relatively more simple fighting gameplay. By that I mean in Brawlhalla everyone has the same exact light and heavy attacks, until a weapon is picked up. Each character has two weapons and no characters share both of these weapons but some have at least one weapon similar to another. The thing that causes these characters to be unique to one another is their heavy attacks which are called Signature attacks or signatures for short but the community usually just calls them sigs.

After wasting that many hours on the game, I've come to a conclusion that it wasn't worth it. More I was diving into knowing the community and the game itself, the more I see that developers just either don't care or don't know what they should do.
First of all, In this game you can buy taunts, to be toxic to your opponent for real money. So this game monetized toxicity. So questions why this community IS toxic falls behind after knowing that the game wants you to be toxic and doesn't punish toxic behaviour.
Second of all, bad ranking system. We have standart elo system and all, but the main problem comes with an eazy opportunity to make alt and because of that you see many "smurfs" on your elo. Also the system with ranks itself. I kinda like how in League (or at least Tft) if you got platinum for example, you can't lose it anymore. You will be stuck there, but you won't lose plat. And there's Brawlhalla, where every lose in ranking game makes you want to die or be toxic (again).
Third of all.. Lack af actually good updates. The only things that Brawlhalla introduces is more legends and skins to buy, new battlepass to make more money... But, where is the normal 2v2 update with friendly fire that majority of the players want? Where is actually new gameplay? Ranking updates? No, we better make new balance features that will ruin someone's legend pick/gameplay completely!
After being into this game for years, I just can't blindly accept it all. I'm done here.

Brawlhalla has changed drastically ever since the release of this review, and I do not recommend you play this game right now because I do not believe the community in any online game I've encountered, not even other F2P games, is as toxic as this one is. The amount of time I've spent on this game is surprising given the rating I've given it, but I can't recommend Brawlhalla when there are so many better ways to spend your time. Also, if you do not live near one of the game's servers, your connection will be complete garbage as there will always be some sort of input lag. If you've ever played a 2D or 3D fighting game, you'll notice that this game is very unbalanced as the developers basically just cycle through metas to hype up the tournaments. I'm not going to lie, the game is addicting, but I don't recommend it if you have to deal with an absurd amount of toxicity if you're casual and an insanely passive and unbalanced meta if you're playing competitively. Also, I recommend playing with your friends and not taking this game too seriously because the prevalence of the passive float meta is noticeable as early as low diamond, so be forewarned and prepared to deal with it if you plan on playing this game for a long time.

This game saved my life.

I am 51.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

The Platform Fighting Game I needed bc Smash Ultimate Online requires a subscription service (ain't nobody got time for that).

Pros:
- Good Servers
- Free To Play
- Fast Paced, Feels Great To Play
- Free stuff if you watch tourneys on Twitch
- I'm still pretty bad after 300 hours
- Actual Depth in Mechanics and plenty of familiarity like fastfalling, aerials, neutral game and edgeguarding
- Combos and Dodge-reads are like crack cocaine

Cons:
- Can be frustrating when you lose to people that are clearly much worse than you
- Lots of characters means a lot of signatures to learn. This can be a positive
- Heavy spam is annoying (audiowise, too), but I might just be repeating con 1 here

Brawlhalla is a fun interactive smash style game (If you are familiar with super smash from Nintendo) but this game lends a very simple control and easy tone to even new players. It lets you play with about 5 legends to start off with you can earn coins in game to unlock new ones or you can purchase for about ($10 US) a pack of legends to play with. There are events, new legends, and much more. This game is sorta kid friendly as in its bad for the fighting aspect but great for the easy and entertainment value. Overall if you are ready to brawl jump in and join the fun its easy and entertaining and overall a great game.

I'm running out of reasons to play the game. I'm a Diamond player, 2300s, Mako main, generally slightly aggressive style. Getting really fed up with the way that the game is going. Pretty much every single ranked game is the same. I get matched against an Ada who never attacks me and parries uber hard, but as soon as I attack them, they nlight/sair combo me to yellow instantly, or I get matched against a spear/bow legend that does the same. I feel like the margin of error on a lot of weapons is totally fucked. When I miss an attack my window to be punished is so massive, and people abuse take advantage of. My main issue here is the strategy of uber parrying then punishing. I see basically zero way to counter it because the other player just always spot dodges and then from there it's a gimp that I can't fight. I don't know what to do. I'm losing 25 elo a game and winning 8 on the rare occasion that I win. I'm not denying that gimping takes really good reading and all that, but I feel like very rarely I lose a game because the other player is actually more skilled than I am. It usually goes like this when I lose: "lol ur complete shit get fuckin rekt you jew/ez/go die/etc" and when I win it's "reported, mako OP/MAKO IS SO OP OMG KILL ME/FUCK YOU FISH FAG" and it just baffles me. The best part is that whenever I actually try to discuss something with these parry players they immediately get super defensive. Unpopular opinion due to high sodium: parrying is a scummy way to play and parry players are dicks about it. I am really having a hard time seeing a reason to continue playing the game, but I love it a lot. I don't know what to do. I know that some of this has to be on me for not playing correctly, but it can't all be my fault when I miss one attack and get gimped off of the map. In all honesty I believe that makos greatsword is clunky and underpowered and needs a tremendous buff. On top of this mako also has some of the worst signatures in-game and it baffles me that with all these hindrances on my terrible character people still trash talk me for losing. Of course the worst character in-game would lose to an overpowered bow character.

What is heroin?
Heroin is a very addictive drug made from morphine, a psychoactive (mind-altering) substance taken from the resin of the seed pod of the opium poppy plant. Heroin’s color and look depend on how it is made and what else it may be mixed with. It can be white or brown powder, or a black, sticky substance called “black tar heroin.”

Heroin is part of a class of drugs called opioids. Other opioids include some prescription pain relievers, such as codeine, oxycodone, and hydrocodone.

Heroin use and overdose deaths have dramatically increased over the last decade. This increase is related to the growing number of people misusing prescription opioid pain relievers like OxyContin and Vicodin. Some people who become addicted to those drugs switch to heroin because it produces similar effects but is cheaper and easier to get. 

In fact, most people who use heroin report they first misused prescription opioids, but it is a small percentage of people who switch to heroin. The numbers of people misusing prescription drugs is so high, that even a small percentage translates to hundreds of thousands of heroin users.1 Even so, some research suggests about one-third of heroin users in treatment simply started with heroin. Maybe they were mistakenly told that only one use cannot lead to addiction. Both heroin and opioid pill use can lead to addiction and overdose. 

How Heroin is Used
Heroin is mixed with water and injected with a needle. It can also be sniffed, smoked, or snorted. People who use heroin sometimes combine it with other drugs, such as alcohol or cocaine (a “speedball”), which can be particularly dangerous and raise the risk of overdose.

According to all known laws
of aviation,

  
there is no way a bee
should be able to fly.

  
Its wings are too small to get
its fat little body off the ground.

  
The bee, of course, flies anyway

  
because bees don't care
what humans think is impossible.

  
Yellow, black. Yellow, black.
Yellow, black. Yellow, black.

  
Ooh, black and yellow!
Let's shake it up a little.

  
Barry! Breakfast is ready!

  
Ooming!

  
Hang on a second.

  
Hello?

  
- Barry?
- Adam?

  
- Oan you believe this is happening?
- I can't. I'll pick you up.

  
Looking sharp.

  
Use the stairs. Your father
paid good money for those.

  
Sorry. I'm excited.

  
Here's the graduate.
We're very proud of you, son.

  
A perfect report card, all B's.

  
Very proud.

  
Ma! I got a thing going here.

  
- You got lint on your fuzz.
- Ow! That's me!

  
- Wave to us! We'll be in row 118,000.
- Bye!

  
Barry, I told you,
stop flying in the house!

  
- Hey, Adam.
- Hey, Barry.

  
- Is that fuzz gel?
- A little. Special day, graduation.

  
Never thought I'd make it.

  
Three days grade school,
three days high school.

  
Those were awkward.

  
Three days college. I'm glad I took
a day and hitchhiked around the hive.

  
You did come back different.

  
- Hi, Barry.
- Artie, growing a mustache? Looks good.

  
- Hear about Frankie?
- Yeah.

  
- You going to the funeral?
- No, I'm not going.

  
Everybody knows,
sting someone, you die.

  
Don't waste it on a squirrel.
Such a hothead.

  
I guess he could have
just gotten out of the way.

  
I love this incorporating
an amusement park into our day.

  
That's why we don't need vacations.

  
Boy, quite a bit of pomp...
under the circumstances.

  
- Well, Adam, today we are men.
- We are!

  
- Bee-men.
- Amen!

  
Hallelujah!

  
Students, faculty, distinguished bees,

  
please welcome Dean Buzzwell.

  
Welcome, New Hive Oity
graduating class of...

  
...9:15.

  
That concludes our ceremonies.

  
And begins your career
at Honex Industries!

  
Will we pick ourjob today?

  
I heard it's just orientation.

  
Heads up! Here we go.

  
Keep your hands and antennas
inside the tram at all times.

  
- Wonder what it'll be like?
- A little scary.

  
Welcome to Honex,
a division of Honesco

  
and a part of the Hexagon Group.

  
This is it!

  
Wow.

  
Wow.

I'll be upfront with this, I hate this game. I hate it so much I'd quit whenever I have the chance to, however that chance will probably never come. The only reason why I play brawhalla is because there aren't really any competitors, the game struggles quite a lot in terms of balance and focuses much more on micro-transactions than the characters. Signature moves are basically all you need in this game, sure you can punish them but with what? A sig? That won't happen if they miss they can just do it again, the game's servers aren't even that good and lag is most of the time inevitable (it literally makes you jump off the map). Unfortunately as I've stated previously, there isn't any competition so my friends and I keep coming back to this game. This game has it's ups and downs but for the most part it is enjoyable to say the least, just make sure to play with friends (ranked is the absolute worst when you factor in all of my previous statements such as lag and sig spamming). At least it's free to play so I can't complain. In the end I didn't lose money but lost most of my sanity.

A pretty good game but I stop playing as much as before. 

<First, it's a 2D fighting game and platforms are involved, performing well timed combos and getting good at movement are the basics of the game.> 
I enjoyed the sense of accomplishment when I got a good combo on the opponent and play my fair share of platforming game, so the game was easy to pick up. Like everything else you need to practice to get better, but you get the sense of achievement every time you beat someone and that was worth chasing for in my opinion. 
In the end, I got good enough to reach mid platinum in my peak and put 1000 hrs in, so no doubt the game is engaging to say the least. 

<However, this game is horrible on a 60Hz monitor, because of how the game was coded.>
 Input lags and frame skipping happened a lot when I was playing, making it inconsistent to play well when the timing of everything off by a few seconds randomly. Also, I play with no sound since the sound lagged behind when the internet is only SLIGHTLY bad. I don't understand why I can play League of Legends and Valorant so smoothly when a 2D cartoon-ish game is the one my internet can't handle.

<The game sure has some technical issues, but the gameplay itself is excellent.>
 The devs constantly patch up problems with constant content update and continue to make improvements. Although I heard complaints about the balance time to time but compare to LoL and Hearthstone, it's pretty much a paradise with no game breaking problems.

<Toxicity was another problem, which I didn't felt too big compare to LoL. >
Now that they even removed all chat after match, I feel like it shouldn't be a problem.

<To sum up, I do recommend the game. >
There are problems but it might matter more or less to the person playing. To me, the technical issue made improving hard for me, resulting in less game play time.

The FitnessGram PACER Test is a multistage aerobic capacity test that progressively gets more difficult as it continues.

The test is used to measure a student's aerobic capacity as part of the FitnessGram assessment. Students run back and forth as many times as they can, each lap signaled by a beep sound. The test get progressively faster as it continues until the student reaches their max lap score.

The PACER Test score is combined in the FitnessGram software with scores for muscular strength, endurance, flexibility and body composition to determine whether a student is in the Healthy Fitness Zone™ or the Needs Improvement Zone™.

My name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

This game is awesome, I really think it´s the best 2d platform fighting game, made a lot of friends and I had ton of fun playing as well as normally expected some rages, the ranked system is great, but it could do better, but if you just want to go out there and prove your skills against someone of your level it´s an incredible experience since you match players that are very similar in skill as you. You start with an elo that it´s not so good for beginners so expect to lose a lot at first, but then when your elo is corrected the experience is really good, the mechanics of this game are awesome and fun. I really find it really interesting that you can go and learn, practice a lot of movements and there is ton of youtube tutorials about how to master them, It´s good to know that you can choose either to master the game or just have fun, mostly like any other competitive game. I really recommend this game, it´s one of the best games that I´ve played in my entire life and one of the few that I actually spend money into.

Basically, it's a good game. You can play it with friends and have fun.

But... if you play ranked, you encounter a 99% toxic community.
It is perceived as "skill", to throw away the spawned weapon and attack the unarmed respawning enemy.
There is a veeery thin part of the community, who are honorable enough to let the enemy pick a weapon to have an even and actually skilled fight, but the rest of the community uses this low level "technique" to win by advantage. It's not about skill, it's about playing trashy and spamming with fast classes. And this goes on even in developer streams or tournaments. It's like spawncamping has become skilled.

It once has been voted the most the devs should do something against the toxicity of the community, but by cherishing this behaviour, they are feeding it.

Also, the classes are barely balanced. The classes in the higher tiers are quick ones, which means there is a meta.

People often complain that weapons are broken or legends are too strong, but it all depends on how you play. 

If you wish to play, watch Lormen's video on the Brawlhalla mindset, to get a proper approach to the game.
Be open-minded. Each legend is unique, so I suggest experimenting until you find one or two that suit your playstyle. 

That said, I definitely recommend this game! The mechanics are well-made and I personally love the art style, animations, and OST. 
It's especially fun (or nerve-wracking) when you play with friends. Hilarious antics will ensue and competition will get fierce. Play alone or together against the world and you shall experience the thrill of victory or the agony of losing ELO in Ranked.

And it's completely free, with lots of generous battle passes that are enjoyable, and free stuff from Twitch streams they provide. The only bad things in this game is occasional toxic enemy players, and the noob sig spammers. PLEASE learn your strings.

This game was once good and i would have recommended it to others, but recently the developers of the game have just been making the game even worse. For example: the weapons are unbalance, they are adding too many files and now the game is becoming more laggy, the crossover signature; and custom signatures in general are literally a competitive advantage and makes the game feel payed to win. Personally i believe there should be a feature to remove custom signatures. Brawlhalla used to be know for their user friendly updates, but now they have recently neglected their already existing player base in favor of attracting new players. At the current rate that the game is going, it would no longer be a 2D platform fighter but rather a game of tag. The developers of the game are taking away to much and adding too much at the same making the game laggy and unbalanced. I don't think that the game developers see the number of players leaving the game, but they're many. Do you think that is good for the community?? at all?? I am becoming very annoyed and bored of this game because nothing is fair anymore!! I am sick and tire of the terrible matchmaking, i am sick and tire of the game being developed around tournaments and not the community (and by tournaments i mean to 64). I am sick and tired of this game Brawlhalla!!
